abstract: This short paper will present a work in progress pertaining to the applicability of Derrida's theory of the archive to emerging forms of archive, such as multiply curated digital archive like Facebook. Preliminary findings are grounded in a pilot study consisting of empirical research conducted with four participants. Additional interviews will be conducted in the early months of 2014. Findings from these interviews will be included in my proposed short paper at DH2014. In addition to presenting the aforementioned empirical research, this proposed short paper will also describe an interactive exhibit called FeverBook, which is being designed through both iterative design and participatory design processes. The FeverBook exhibit is intended to afford users the ability to experience firsthand the effects of such Derridian notions as 'violence,' 'spectrality,' and 'troubling' as they pertain to a fictive Facebook account.
article_title: Generative Troubling in Emerging Archival Forms

affiliation: University of California, Irvine, United States of America

article_title: Constructing Scientific Archives that Support Humanistic Research

affiliation: Michigan State University, United States of America

abstract: Casta paintings, an eighteenth century genre of non-religious New Spanish art, depicts interracial unions and their offspring involved in various everyday activities. In this study, we have built a database with a corpus of over two hundred paintings and described the characters depicted in them by caste, gender, and activity. We provide an analysis to challenge the artificial division of castes presented in these paintings by providing insights into the underlying aspects of mestizaje such labor division. Our study identifies the paradox between the intent of the paintings to reaffirm the Spanish prominence in the Americas and the implicit anticipation of the demise of Spanish colonial rule.
article_title: The Landscapes of Casta Paintings: Depictions of Social Anxieties in XVIII Century New Spanish Art

abstract: In this paper, we present a critical evaluation of the intended levels of design empowerment in various Web 2.0-based social and geographic applications (Geoweb 2.0). This evaluation covers a survey of eleven cases which specifically relate to urban and spatial issues (OpenPlans, Nextdoor, CitySourced, Neighborland, LocalWiki, Spacehive, MindMixer,LocalData, mySociety, Ideavibes, Community Planit ). By this way, we aim to provide an insight into the inclusion strategies and tools employed for Geoweb 2.0-supported citizen involvement.   As a result, we observed that the aforementioned organizations view higher levels of design empowerment as secondary priorities. According to the survey participants, their focus was on data collection and providing information rather than active citizen empowerment in collaborative urban design processes.
article_title: Geoweb 2.0 and Design Empowerment: A Critical Evaluation of Eleven Cases

abstract: This study explores the possibility of extrapolating results from state-of-the-art research on attractiveness and beauty, to the analysis of faces in world painting. With identified traits of the faces detected by a face recognition algorithm, and based on meta-analysis of symmetry and averageness, we establish some clues on whether faces across time should be considered more beautiful, and when these trends occur.
article_title: The Changing Canon of Beauty: Facial Attractiveness in the Representation of Human Faces in World Painting

abstract: Discussion of the role of academic libraries in Digital Humanities projects, as well as a presentation of how this role is fulfilled by the University Library in general, and the Arts Faculty Library in particular, at KU Leuven (Belgium).
article_title: The opportunistic librarian: A Leuven confession
Crowdsourcing Performing Arts History with NYPL's ENSEMBLE
Two new tools for multimodal editions

abstract: Using unsupervised and supervised Naïve Bayes classification to examine 16 orthographic variables in ~50 million words from the archive of the University of British Columbia's student newspaper, I find that multiple variants occur in predictable contexts. That is, in this Canadian medium where editorial oversight on orthographic convention is minimal, color prefers different contexts than colour to the extent that we can predict the variant given its surrounding words with surprising accuracy. While this would seem to critique language external motivations for variant selection -- specifically the orthography/identity connection advocated by Heffernan et al. (2010) who argue for a connection between ideology and orthography in the Canadian context -- these contexts are themselves ideologically motivated as they tend to take the form of differentially oriented advertisements, or, as I term them, 'solicitations'. Combining computational with more traditional sociolinguistic techniques, this paper proposes the identity/orthography connection in more proximal, more interactional terms.
article_title: Does colour mean color?: Disambiguating word sense and ideology in British and American orthographic variants

abstract: We describe the design and implementation of a plan to integrate a manuscript matching scheme into a coherent and efficient system that can help scholars find the best candidates for potential joins for any given fragment.
article_title: Where is my Other Half?

abstract: This work addresses the problem of story classification in large folklore collections by combining human labeling and feedback with machine-learning techniques for identifying topics in text corpora. We describe a series of experiments conducted on a collection of approximately 35,000 Danish folklore records and explain our primary findings: 1) that computational cross-validation of traditional human indexes is effective at uncovering "liminal" stories that are mislabeled and overlooked in the original classification scheme but prove to be of great interest to present-day scholars; and 2) that automatically propagating multiple labeled topics from a modern research-oriented index across a large folklore collection performs best when combined with expert human feedback.
article_title: The Telltale Hat: LDA and Classification Problems in a Large Folklore Corpus

affiliation: Cornell University Department of Information Science
UCLA Scandinavian Section and Department of Asian Languages and Cultures

abstract: In 2013, the DigCurV collaborative network completed development of a Curriculum Framework for digital curation skills in the European cultural heritage sector.
article_title: DigCurV: curriculum framework for digital curation in the cultural heritage sector

abstract: This paper presents on-going work on analyzing strategies for argumentation via automatic means, using public data from a German arbitration. In addition to a thorough linguistic analysis of the relevant parameters, we provide a computational implementation that automatically annotates the corpus with respect to pragmatically relevant features.  The annotated data is used in a visual analysis system which shows overall patterns of the discourse as well as detailed views on the data.
article_title: Towards visualizing linguistic patterns of deliberation: a case study of the S21 arbitration

abstract: Given the rapid growth of linguistic and historical datasets, and recent developments in information retrieval, we can begin to think about new computational approaches to discourse analysis across a wide variety of text corpora.This paper presents one such approach, using a Latent Dirichelet Allocation (LDA) topic modeling algorithm to analyse the more than 74,000 articles contained in the 18th-century French Encyclopédie. In deploying topic modeling as a discourse analysis tool, we aim to highlight the unique discursive makeup of encyclopaedic articles, treating them as a combination of various discourses independent of their original disciplinary classification. Some of these discourses might have been lost to the modern reader through the classification process itself, and others may prove useful in uncovering interdisciplinary connections between classes that would have otherwise gone unnoticed. This approach can then be used to identify similar 'philosophic' or Enlightenment discourses underpinning a wide variety of contemporary 18th-century texts.
article_title: Discourses and Disciplines in the Enlightenment: Topic Modeling the French Encyclopédie

abstract: Our results demonstrate that Patterson, like Dumas, has commodified his reputation as an author. Patterson is not guilty of the literary crimes of which Dumas is accused, but it is nonetheless interesting to see that his approach to authorship is not entirely novel. In this paper, we will discuss our analysis in the context of these publishing practices, both new and old, and how literary collaborations might be approached from a stylometric perspective, using Patterson and his reinvention of the industry as a useful test case.
article_title: Beyond Style: Literary Capitalism and the Publishing Industry

affiliation: Pennsylvania State University / University College Cork

abstract: Accounting documents are well suited to be reproduced with the computer: they contain a significant number of highly structured information which was meant already in its original context to be calculated. Creating a database for executing statistical and numerical analysis of the data seems to be a promising method to deal with these documents. This assumption isn’t reflected in the practice of critical scholarly editions of accounting books. The paper proposes a model to edit this kind of documents integrating the strength of the TEI for transcription and linguistical representation with standards for the description of economic documents (XBRL) and content oriented representation in RDF.
article_title: Modelling digital edition of medieval and early modern accounting documents

affiliation: Zentrum für Informationsmodellierung - Austrian Centre for Digital Humanities, Universität Graz

keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: The Lacuna Stories Project is a cross-disciplinary collaboration that includes faculty whose research interests span literature, pedagogy, historical thinking, public humanities, and platform studies. This short paper will describe the research and pedagogical goals of the Lacuna Stories Project as well as the technological innovations developed to support these goals. By the time of the conference, Amir Eshel (PI) and Brian Johnsrud (Project Manager) will have taught a course during Stanford's Winter Quarter in which students use the Lacuna Stories Platform in and outside the classroom. Johnsrud and Michael Widner (Technology Director) will also have taught a course in the same quarter on building in the digital humanities that will use Lacuna Stories as its primary example. This paper will touch upon how the prototype encouraged student learning and collaboration by presenting our data gathered from student use, interviews, and focus groups.
article_title: Lacuna Stories: Building an Annotation Platform for Historical Thinking

abstract: This short paper describes how a small-scale implementation of big data text analysis can be used to read single texts and test algorithmic processes. A proximate use of “distant reading” is used to render texts productively unfamiliar and show how distributed computing systems structure typographically experimental literary texts.
article_title: Small-Scale Big Data: Experimental Literature and Distributed Computing

affiliation: University of Victoria, Electronic Textual Cultures Lab

abstract: We propose a quantitative analysis framework for scripts that is largely computational and requires minimal user interaction. The framework is based on various methods and techniques employed in the field of graphonomics. It is grounded on the principles of handwriting production and handwriting analysis. We explore various features used in the related area of gesture design and recognition and their application to the analysis of scripts. The computed quantitative features could serve as descriptors for scripts, and  be used for comparing and analyzing scripts. This is especially applicable to the field of paleography, where such quantitative features are much needed. We also present a prototype implementation of the proposed framework.
article_title: Framework for Quantitative Analysis of Scripts

abstract: Also in the age of electronic publishing print publications often remain the points of reference. Paper remains the principal scholarly format accepted in many circles and in spite of all activities on long-term digital archiving, it remains a central medium to disseminate and conserve patrimonial content over the decades and centuries. However, how can you combine an XML-based workflow with the need to publish high-quality, multilingual print output respecting the often arcane typesetting requirements of scholarly texts in humanities publishing and notably in the realm of critical editions? This is the starting point of the DFG-funded XML-Print, an Open Source project that tackles the typesetting requirements for multilingual critical editions while offering a user-friendly frontend.
article_title: XML-Print.  Typesetting arbitrary XML documents in high quality

abstract: For most of the world's 7000 languages there are few records available via the internet. Efforts to increase the documentation of these small languages have led to the development of tools and repositories over the past decade. However, not all digital language archives currently provide metadata to the Open Language Archives Community, rendering their collections invisible to their aggregated search. While repository webpages may be accessible to web-searches, they do not allow the targeted search by language that is the focus of OLAC’s aggregator. Other repositories (including many institutional repositories—national libraries and archives, mission archives and so on) have language content that is not noted in the collection’s catalog, Finally, there are collections still held by their creators and not in a repository at all. In this paper I present the results of a survey trying to locate such collections and identify features that could make more information more freely available, and suggest that it is a DH project to create repositories.
article_title: What remains to be done – Exposing invisible collections in the other 6500 languages and why it is a DH enterprise.

abstract: This paper will analyse, describe and evaluate the first full public release of HuNI - the Humanities Networked Infrastructure. It will include a demonstration of the full functionality of the service, and will report on its uptake by researchers and the wider community. We will also discuss the lessons learned from this large-scale project over its two-year lifespan, and the measures taken to ensure the sustainability of the HuNI service beyond the life of the project. The paper will focus, in particular, on the ways in which HuNI is changing the nature of humanities research in the areas of data sharing, collaboration, community involvement, and the creation of socially linked data.
article_title: Socially-Derived Linking and Data Sharing within a Virtual Laboratory for the Humanities

abstract: In this paper we investigate the possibility to adapt existing lexical resources and Natural Language Processing (NLP) methodologies related to Sentiment Analysis (SA) to the historical domain. The corpus used for our research is the complete corpus of writings of Alcide De Gasperi (1881-1954), one of the founders of the Italian Republic, made of about 3,000 documents and 3,000,000 words. Using this corpus as a case study, two experiments have been carried out and are described in this paper. The aim of these experiments were the evaluation of i) how existing lexical resources for SA perform in the historical domain and ii) the feasibility of a sentiment annotation task for historical texts either for expert annotators and for crowdsourcing workers.
article_title: Sentiment Analysis for the Humanities: the Case of Historical Texts

affiliation: Fondazione Bruno Kessler / University of Trento

abstract: A presentation of a new online environment for the production of a major critical edition of the Greek New Testament, including interfaces for XML transcription and automatic collation.
article_title: The Workspace for Collaborative Editing

affiliation: Institute for Textual Scholarship and Electronic Editing (ITSEE), University of Birmingham
Trier Center for Digital Humanities (Kompetenzzentrum für elektronische Erschließungs- und Publikationsverfahren in den Geisteswissenschaften, Universität Trier)
Institute for Textual Scholarship and Electronic Editing (ITSEE), University of Birmingham

abstract: The paper presents a conceptual model for the editorial domain, providing a conceptual definition for entities such as document, text, work, user and author within such domain.
article_title: Modelling digital editing: of texts, documents and works
keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: Digital Humanities (DH) is becoming an increasingly global community of practice with international initiatives such as centerNet, Global Outlook::Digital Humanities, the Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations, the Digging into Data Challenge and many others. With advances in telecommunications and information technology, these types of collaborations are no longer bound by geography. However, as documented elsewhere, challenges stemming from geographical distance must be managed to ensure that teams are work together successfully. One of the primary challenges is finding ways to facilitate communication and coordination across distance and time. Skype and other internet-enabled tools provide some potential to accomplish this; however, little knowledge exists on the best way to use these tools within a geographically dispersed collaboration. This paper will contribute to this discussion with an examination of the experiences of a DH lab using an open communication channel through Skype to connect team members located in different sites.
article_title: The potential of open computer-mediated communication channels to facilitate collaboration in geographically distributed collaborations

abstract: This paper presents three recent case studies (J.K. Rowling, Edgar Allan Poe, and "Bilbo Baggins") in authorship attribution and shows how the same analytic protocol can be used to answer each case.   This protocol can be easily used by third parties and the error rate can be established at any desired boundary.  We offer this protocol as a base for the development of possible standard methods  for further scholarship.
article_title: The Rowling Case: A Proposed Standard Analytic Protocol for Authorship Questions

abstract: Recent forms of scholarly editions like social editions require different ways of ensuring transparency, reversibility, and reliability. As we have to deal with dynamic editions, which do not represent a final state, we should put our focus on editorial processes. This paper will examine how these processes can be documented for scholarly editions. Based on results from domains where processes and process documentation are fundamental, like business process management and enterprise content management, it will discuss prerequisites and central issues of documenting single editorial activities. This includes how and to which extent process data can be generated and how process related data can be incorporated into scholarly editions. The paper will also address usage scenarios for such data in the creation and usage of digital scholarly editions.
article_title: Process Data for Digital Scholarly Editions

abstract: In this paper we will present a project of a collection of digital editions of Medieval French texts carried out by the team of the BFM Old French Corpus (http://txm.bfm-corpus.org). The need for such a collection is urgent, as commercial publishers keep trying to obtain exclusive rights on the editions they print, which makes it impossible to include these resources into publisher-independent text corpora or to analyse and annotate them in the framework of research projects. The texts of the BFM collection will be downloadable under a CC license, and they will be integrated to the main BFM corpus for search and analysis. TXM portal technology will be used to publish the collection on the web. Innovative editing rules (including multi-layer transcriptions of the primary sources) worked out in the _Queste del saint Graal_ digital edition project will be applied in the BFM collection.
article_title: BFM Collection - Open-Source Digital Editions of Medieval French Texts

abstract: The contribution will present the digital genetic edition of the notebooks of the Austrian conceptual artist Hartmut Skerbisch. The central research question is how a digital genetic and semantically enriched edition can support the appreciation of an artist’s concepts and associations during the process of a work’s creation.  Therefore, prominent issues are (1) identifying the need for editions of (hand)written sources in art historical research, (2) addressing the difficulties in encoding the origination process of an edition and the application of the TEI recommendations for genetic edition to resolve them, and (3) using semantic annotation of concepts to track influences and association processes of the artist in order to facilitate the interpretation and comprehension of his work.
article_title: Hartmut Skerbisch – Envisioning association processes of a conceptual artist

affiliation: Centre for Information Modelling, University of Graz

abstract: Ontologies are widely employed as formal shared vocabularies for many domains of knowledge. However, for some domains there is a variety of ontologies instead of one standard vocabulary. These ontologies are typically quite semantically diverse since they were constructed by different experts who possess contrary viewpoints on the domain. Reaching consensus and maximizing the agreement between the diverse ontologies constitutes a big research challenge, especially for controversial domains, such as cultural heritage. The goal of this research is to explore ways for maximizing inter-ontology agreement. We proposed a collaborative scheme for user evaluation of ontological relations. Our experimental results, based on the devised local and global agree-ment measures, show that collaborative evaluation can significantly improve the agreement between ontologies. Furthermore, despite the diversity of viewpoints, based on these evaluation scores most of the consensual truthful relations can be revealed and unified into one standard vocabulary.
article_title: Collaboratively maximizing inter-ontology agreement for controversial domains: A case study of Jewish cultural heritage

abstract: In this paper I use topic models to identify the most common discourses used by Russian newspapesr to express Russia’s relations with the North Caucasus region. I then use grammatical features of news texts to identify three styles or genres of news report. Pro-Kremlin texts about Chechnya are overwhelmingly factual  news reports; oppositional texts tend to be analytical or emotional. Using the example of Beslan I show that this divergence coincided increased political control over Russian news media
article_title: Beslan and the disappearance of opinion

abstract: In this paper we present the results of a survey of the Spanish and Portuguese speaking community of digital humanists done between June and October 2013. The data collected was used to carry out network and central tendencies analyses, and further used to build an interactive map visualization using the DARIAH-DE Geo-Browser. We have been able to identify key patterns characterizing this community. In terms of disciplines, two stand out: the central location of Literary Studies as a meeting point, and the extended influence of Information Science and History joining together most of the other fields included. Additionally, we provide insights into patterns of collaboration and shared approaches distinctive of this community. Furthermore, the extended - and almost strategic - geographic distribution of the survey's participants suggests that thanks to the ties with other DH communities (Anglo-American, and Continental-European), Spanish and Portuguese speaking DHers have the potential to bridge and incorporate distinct practices and approaches.  Other insights regarding the historical development, collaboration practices, and work locations are also dealt with in the long version of this paper.
article_title: MapaHD: Exploring Spanish and Portuguese Speaking DH Communities

affiliation: CulturePlex Lab / University of Western Ontario

keywords: digital humanities - nature and significance networks

article_title: Using Computer Vision to Improve Image Metadata

abstract: In this paper we argue that the extent to which annotations are interoperable will depend on the degree to which research context and intentions of annotations can be modelled in the annotation. Furthermore, we propose that metadata of this kind will be able to generate surplus value for humanities research. Building on work from DARIAH-DE we set out here a basic idea for defining a motivation ontology to use with the oa:motivatedBy predicate in OA. Finally we relate existing discussions about oa:motivatedBy with the topic of provenance.
article_title: Digital Humanists Are Motivated Annotators

abstract: Thracian coins, found in museums and private collections throughout the world, can be virtually collected in an online data base that is free and open to the public.
article_title: The Ancient Coins of Thrace: A Numismatic Web Portal

abstract: Researchers of the Visionary Cross project are developing a browsing environment for a mixed media edition of the Dream of the Rood poem (both the full manuscript version and the fragment preserved on a standing stone cross). The new possibilities offered by a dynamic framework also pose very specific issues about how to combine heterogeneous media and how to provide for a varied audience, especially for the most advanced users. This paper will describe how these methodological issues have been tackled by the project members.
article_title: Mixed data, mixed audience: building a flexible platform for the Visionary Cross project

abstract: Our ongoing project presents an activist model grounded in the classroom where undergraduate students are participants in canon expansion while learning valuable research and digital literary skills.  Using Omeka as a technological bridge, two undergraduate classes from disparate universities are building White Violence and Black Resistance in Texas, an archive-based digital recovery project. Our project is developed to answer two challenges in current digital humanities practice.  First, we view our project as a way to leverage expertise and resources across historical areas of divide. Second, our project focuses on the recovery of cultural objects that have not been included in digital collections. Our project provides a replicable model that we believe will empower other teachers and students to engage with digital humanities.
article_title: Digital Activism:  Canon Expansion and Textual Recovery in the Undergraduate Classroom

abstract: This paper presents the findings of a case study of Welsh Newspapers Online. It demonstrates, through detailed content web log analysis, that while users are deeply engaged with digital newspaper collections, they tend not to browse newspapers. This confirms suspicions that users interact with digital newspapers online differently to the physical objects.
article_title: Exploring Usage of Digital Newspaper Archives through Web Log Analysis: A Case Study of Welsh Newspapers Online

abstract: This research began in a class taught by Matthew Jockers and has continued under his direction as a project of the newly formed Nebraska Literary Lab. Our work focused on mining the fiction and non-fiction works of Willa Cather that are housed in the Willa Cather Archive at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (Jewell, Andrew. The Willa Cather Archive. U of Nebraska-Lincoln, 2004-2013. Web.). Largely regarded as a private person, Cather forbade the publication of her correspondences; only within the past year have her letters finally been published. With the publication of these letter comes the unique opportunity for scholars to research Cather’s personal thoughts and voice. Our research focused on using stylometrics to explore the ways in which the voice Cather used in her correspondences differs from the voice she used in her public writing; our conclusions point to similarities between Cather’s novel My Mortal Enemy, a work noted for both its economy of style and autobiographical features, and her recently published letters.
article_title: Exploring the Intersection of Personal and Public Authorial Voice in the Works of Willa Cather

affiliation: Nebraska Literary Lab, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Nebraska Literary Lab, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Nebraska Literary Lab, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Nebraska Literary Lab, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

abstract: STAK is a prototype for a web-based locative app that will enhance the physical library experience for the humanities researcher. This paper details the results of user-studies that led to this prototype, and the development of a user-model for humanities scholars in the library stacks.
article_title: STAK – Serendipitous Tool for Augmenting Knowledge: Bridging Gaps between Digital and Physical Resources

abstract: The following proposal presents the results of a longitudinal study of reading in both digital and physical environments carried out as part of the INKE project, by researchers at the UCL Centre for Digital Humanities from 2009-2013. Our aim was to understand how different digital devices and physical, printed publications are used, and integrated into reader behaviour. It took place at a time of rapid change in the technology of reading in digital environments: the Kindle, iPad, and other tablet computers were launched, and quickly became popular, during the period of the study. We might hypothesise, therefore, that such a period would usher in the transformation of the reading experience, and wholesale move from paper to digital devices and ebooks which had been predicted in the literature. Our study of reading behaviour provides evidence against which to test such claims.
article_title: The dog that didn’t bark: A longitudinal study of reading behaviour in physical and digital environments

abstract: This paper presents a suite of procedural rules for creating 3D models of Roman and Hellenistic architecture and urban environments. Unlike traditional 3D modeling software, which uses polygons to simulate form, procedural modeling entails the use of computer programming languages to write a semantic description of a building that then generates a polygonal model.  Procedural modeling has the potential to address a number of issues related to 3D archaeological reconstructions which are of concern to digital humanists. Of particular interest for archaeologists and architectural historians is the ability to test hypothetical reconstructions of ancient architecture in a fully realized urban context. The procedural rules link each iteration of a model to its source material, allowing the degree of certainty present in each model to be accurately defined through the documentation of each step in the process of interpreting a given data set. Procedural modeling thus enhances the scholarly value of architectural reconstructions by providing a platform for the comparison and refutation of 3D visualizations.
article_title: An Integrated Approach to the Procedural Modeling of Ancient Cities and Buildings

abstract: Arch-V is an NEH funded project to develop software to provide image based search and retrieval of digital archives of print material.  Originally developed for and implemented by the English Broadside Ballad Archive (EBBA), this Short Paper will introduce Arch-V and provide information on how it can be implemented by other archives.
article_title: Arch-V:  A Platform for Image-Based Search and Retrieval of Digital Archives

abstract: This paper analyzes how digitized newspaper databases can be used in historical research on identity formation in public discourse. It discusses a new semantic text mining tool, Texcavator, which is currently being developed in the Dutch research program 'Translantis: Digital Humanities Approaches to Reference Cultures'.The paper presents a case study which combines the Texcavator tool with the publicly available Delpher and with traditional historical methods in order to analyze identity formation of health risk groups in Dutch public discourse in the twentieth century.
article_title: Using digitized newspaper archives to investigate identity formation in long-term public discourse

abstract: Although sound studies and interdisciplinary music and poetry scholarship have increased over the last decade, scholars have not had the digital tools necessary to make their musico-literary arguments accessible to a wider audience. This talk will present two tools that will help change that:  'Songs of the Victorians,' an archive and analysis of parlor and art song settings of Victorian poems, and 'Augmented Notes,' a tool that lets users build their own interdisciplinary websites like 'Songs of the Victorians.'
article_title: Integrating Score and Sound:  “Augmented Notes” and the Advent of Interdisciplinary Publishing Frameworks

abstract: The goal of the project is to create a tool for assisting the researchers in European Integration Studies in the analysis of legal documents, i.e. the treaties of the EU. The system should allow the user to navigate through the treaties along with different axes of inquiry: access to a particular unit inside a treaty (part, section, chapter, article, etc.); multilingual alignment; modifications operated upon or by a treaty and the history of its different (consolidated) versions; status (entered into forced, repealed); possibility to add and retrieve user’s comments.
article_title: Building a multi-dimensional space for the analysis of  European Integration Treaties. An XML-TEI scenario

abstract: Systemic Functional Linguistics as a theory of language facilitates the analysis of the architecture of language and the strategic choices at work within its temporal and contextual use. It enables the analysis of and detection of hate speech within texts in an online environment.  Hate speech is compounded through lexical cohesion. This research reports on the team's analysis of a corpus of videos posted to Youtube in which the subjects are dehumanised through hate speech. We argue that using SFL to track the development of lexical cohesion between elements of the text, and within the conversations posted in reaction to the videos, provides the metadata necessary to build an automated alert system that flags dehumanising elements of hate speech as they accrue meaning within their temporal and contextual use.
article_title: Fractures and Cohesion: Using Systemic Functional Linguistics to Detect and Analyse Hate Speech in an Online Environment

affiliation: School of Computing, National College of Ireland

abstract: This paper seeks to explore how the modeling of textual data for humanities research connects to the high-level research questions humanities scholars address in their scholarly writing. It offers a detailed description of the modeling (transcription, text encoding, metadata) and the high-level research goals for two closely related digital collections: the Early Caribbean Digital Archive and the Women Writers Project. It then traces critically the inferential steps by which we seek to get from the data being captured to the theoretical concepts ("culture", "geography", "influence", etc.) that animate the research. The goal of the paper is to provide a much more exacting and thorough understanding of the complexity of data modeling required to support the argumentative nuance and conceptual subtlety of real-world, high-quality humanities research.
article_title: From Markup to Analysis: Culture Claims and Code in the Digital Archive

abstract: Since 2007 we work on the construction and exploitation of a digital tombstone archive for Taiwan. About 170.000 photos of 42.000 tombs have been taken so far on 500 graveyards. In this presentation we will summarize the main aspects of this project to facilitate and encourage the start-up of similar projects and to allow researchers to evaluate the adequacy of the created data archive for their studies. Special attention is given to the semi-automatic data annotation, which involves mostly example-based machine learning approaches, trying to reduce the burden of a manual annotation, while producing still high quality data. Relying essentially on nothing more than a Debian desktop as web and database server and digital GPS-camera, the costs for the hard and software could be kept at an absolute minimum, allowing such a project to repeated even in economically disfavored regions of the world.
article_title: Creating a Digital Tombstone Archive:  From Fieldwork to Theory Formation

affiliation: Institut National des Langues et Civilisations Orientales (INALCO), Paris, France

abstract: This article presents a methodology for systematically documenting metahistorical information (or  paradata) for the encoding of historical data. The methodology allows us, to associate the following to a transcription or data extraction: the author of the process, the research project during which this operation was performed and the pipeline of methods that were used. This metaknowledge is crucial for aligning research data originating from different research groups, using different research approaches. These metadata are also important for the long-term evolution of projects, for which it is necessary to regularly revise data encoding strategies.
article_title: Encoding Metaknowledge for Historical Databases

abstract: Cette contribution émane d’une réflexion menée à l’occasion de la réalisation collective d’un projet de recherche et d’édition numérique XML-TEI des cours dispensés à l’Académie d’architecture par Antoine Desgodets de 1719 à 1728. Trois questions seront développées : d’une part, comment l’utilisation de la Text Encoding Initiative offre une solution adéquate pour traduire la souplesse d’un corpus constitué de textes prononcés à l’oral ? D’autre part, comment des dessins de nature différente (plans d’architecture, figures géométriques) placés dans leur contexte s’énoncent et constituent un discours argumenté ? Enfin, comment réussir grâce au numérique à générer une mise en abyme de normes et de règles juridiques constatée sur un temps long d’un siècle ? La méthode usitée devrait servir de modèle pour ce type de recherche sur la normalisation des disciplines qui, par définition, sont établies à partir de l’oralité avant d’être figées dans l’écrit.
article_title: Matérialiser et rendre perceptible la transmission orale du savoir. L’édition électronique des cours d’Antoine Desgodets à l’Académie royale d’architecture en France, 1719-1728

affiliation: CNRS (France) – UMR 7074, Centre de théorie et analyse du droit

abstract: Trading Consequences is an interdisciplinary research project between historians, computational linguists and visualization specialists. We use text mining and visualisations to explore the growth of the global commodity trade in the nineteenth century. Feedback from a group of environmental historians during a workshop provided essential information to adapt advanced text mining and visualisation techniques to historical research. Expert feedback is an essential tool for effective interdisciplinary research in the digital humanities.
article_title: Trading Consequences: A Case Study of Combining Text Mining & Visualisation to Facilitate Document Exploration

affiliation: ILCC, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh
Department of History, University of Saskatchewan

abstract: This contribution presents an XML schema for annotating a high level narratological category: speech, thought and writing representation (ST&WR). It focusses on two aspects: Firstly, the original schema is presented as an example for the challenge to encode a narrative feature in a structured and flexible way and secondly, ways of adapting this schema to TEI are considered, in order to make it usable for other, TEI-based projects.
article_title: An XML annotation schema for speech, thought and writing representation

abstract: This article presents a study regarding the use of peer-grading in the context of a Digital Humanities class at the masters level. 56 students had to grade the work of their peers, following an explicit notation grid. The results show a high correlation between the peer-grading marks and the professor’s marks. The grades obtained by this method are within an interval of 0.5 points of the professor’s grading in in about ¾ of the cases. We discuss these preliminary results in detail and the relevance of using this approach for a large-scale MOOC on Digital Humanities.
article_title: A Preparatory Analysis of Peer-Grading for a Digital Humanities MOOC

abstract: This presentation will discuss how to get DH started at schools with few technical resources. To get around a lack of technology and technical confidence in my students I had them use smartphones and an open-source Ruby On Rails engine for harvesting Instagram photos to create a modern archive of Shaw University student life, called #myshawu. I will talk about the archive and the technology, display some of the results and trends of exposing low technology users to a digital project, and delve into how DH is an tool for teaching them the skills and critical thinking necessary for true digital empowerment. I will also touch on how the project has grown to include alumni, what it has done for my students, and how this project connects with the larger DH community.
article_title: DH on the Fringes: Using Smartphones, Instagram, and Ruby on Rails to Archive the DH Experience at an HBCU

abstract: This paper will report on the results of the author's research using the methods of distributional semantics to track semantic drift between the Greek Old Testament and the Greek New Testament.
article_title: Tracking Semantic Drift in Ancient Languages: The Bible as Exemplar and Test Case

abstract: Cultural heritage is one of the most significant goods that a county and a culture possesses. The Sudan is a country rich in artefacts that go back to the dawn of history: archaeological remains, art, manuscripts that date back to beginning of Islam, books, archival documents, documentary film, hundreds of thousands of hours of video, television and radio, millions of photographs.  The National Archives alone hold 76 million photographic negatives.  This rich heritage is at risk.  At risk from the heat, dust and humidity, from obsolescence of media: the documentary film in the film archive, for instance, can only be accessed on ancient and deteriorating equipment, for which no spare parts for repair can be found.  These materials record history and culture of the country that is fast disappearing in the modern world.  If these artefacts themselves are lost, so too will be the knowledge of a way of life.  Digital Sudan will transform  Sudanese intellectual productions to modern electronic and digital media, which will be safer to preserve and easier to retrieve.
article_title: Digital Cultural Heritage and the Healing of a Nation: Digital Sudan

abstract: A method to analyze classical Chinese texts is proposed. In the method, we use our original morphological analyzer based on MeCab. We propose a new four-level word-class system for classical Chinese on the MeCab-based analyzer. We design the top level of the word-class system to represent the predicate-object structure of classical Chinese. The second level is the ordinary word-class of classical Chinese, excluding “adjective.” The third and fourth levels are word-subclasses to describe detailed behavior of the words in classical Chinese texts. In order to make corpus for classical Chinese on MeCab, we have constructed a MeCab-corpus editor based on XEmacs CHISE. We use the MeCab-corpus editor to compile our digital corpus and our digital dictionary based on our four-level word-class system for classical Chinese.
article_title: A Morphological Analysis of Classical Chinese Texts

affiliation: Institute for Research in Humanities, Kyoto University, Japan
Faculty of Foreign Language Studies, Kansai University, Japan
Institute for Research in Humanities, Kyoto University, Japan
