abstract: We present Diva.js, a web-based document viewer that provides users with tools for accessing, navigating, and engaging with digitized documents. We compare Diva.js to existing, de-facto methods of displaying document images, and provide technical details on how it functions.
article_title: Accessing, navigating, and engaging with high-resolution document image collections using Diva.js

abstract: We present the “Towards a Digital Dante Encyclopedia” project, a three years Italian National Research Project, that aims at building a prototypical digital library endowed with services supporting scholars in creating, evolving and consulting a digital encyclopedia of Dante Alighieri and of his works.
article_title: Towards a Semantic Network of Dante’s Works and Their Contextual Knowledge

affiliation: Dipartimento di Filologia, Letteratura e Linguistica, Università di Pisa
Dipartimento di Filologia, Letteratura e Linguistica, Università di Pisa

keywords: the creation of humanities digital resources

abstract: The objective of this paper is to  perform new analyses on the structure and evolution of the Incanto system. The hypothesis is to go beyond the textual narrative and cartographic representation—thanks to network analysis—offering a new perspective on this maritime system.
article_title: A Network Analysis Approach of the Venetian Incanto System

abstract: A number of DH tools have been recently developed that aim to re-introduce serendipity to online searches. This paper critically examines four of these tools and makes suggestions for future designs based on library and information science literature.
article_title: Designing the next big thing: Randomness versus serendipity in DH tools

abstract: This paper presents my current research into using computational text analysis for understanding the historical practice of enjambment, a key feature of the poetic line. This research contributes both to the project of sociological poetics, the understanding of literary form in its broadest historical function within human culture, and to the development of a computational poetics.
article_title: Enjambment and the Poetic Line: Towards a Computational Poetics

abstract: How can digital humanities contribute to empowering processes through arts and music? In this long paper, we aim at analysing Tunisian representations of Europe through images, music and video clips. This is part of a broader research project funded by the Swiss National Science Foundation, which engages undocumented mobility in the context of recent developments in Tunisia. Even after the events of the “Arab Spring” and its demands for dignity and liberty, the desire of young men (harragas) to “burn their papers” (harga), to leave their country of first citizenship and to reach Europe is still persistent. Such a desire to escape overall circumstances however cannot be reduced to merely economical motives. Undocumented mobility is by no means a one-dimensional, single-layered process governed by “push-and-pull factors”, but reflects the transnational social imaginaire and its various cultural resources as well.
article_title: Digital Humanities Empowering through Arts and Music. Tunisian Representations of Europe through music and video clips

abstract: Over the two-year grant term for the Early Modern OCR Project (eMOP), our objective is to improve the OCR technology for early modern texts by testing on a 45 million page dataset and publishing an open-source workflow for future OCR projects. eMOP also resolves to create a community of scholars engaged in the digital preservation of cultural materials, which is reflected in the multi-institutional, international team of eMOP collaborators. In effect, eMOP has faced challenges endemic to large DH projects, namely collaboration, outreach, and agile project development, and this panel proposes to present those challenges, discuss our solutions, and extract standards that apply for all large DH projects.
article_title: Navigating the Storm: eMOP, Big DH Projects, and Agile Steering Standards

affiliation: Initiative for Digital Humanities, Media, and Culture at Texas A&M University
Initiative for Digital Humanities, Media, and Culture at Texas A&M University
Initiative for Digital Humanities, Media, and Culture at Texas A&M University
KB National Library of the Netherlands
Illinois Informatics Institute (I3) at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign
Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (PRImA) research Lab at The University of Salford

abstract: This paper focuses on the history of the English lexicon, and on a new approach to this history through the database of the _Historical Thesaurus of English_ (Kay et al 2009). It does so by reference to the semantic space of English, following Lehrer’s statement that ‘the words of a language can be classified into sets which […] divide up the semantic space or the semantic domain in certain ways’. This space is described in this paper as the total accumulation of the various individual semantic fields which make up the language, as represented in the Historical Thesaurus' database. The paper therefore analyses the size of the English lexicon in these semantic clusters over time, including its metaphorical links, and aims to give a digital analysis of the history of English in ways which were previously not possible.
article_title: "Civilization arranged in chronological strata": A digital approach to the English semantic space

abstract: In this paper, we will introduce the disciplinary developments in Estonian humanities that are intertwined with use of digital resources and methods. The aim of the paper is to compare and contrast the use of digital technologies in Estonian humanities to the developments of the field of digital humanities.
article_title: Digital humanities in Estonia: digital divide or linguistic isolation?

abstract: Social media helps create an engaging setting for digital archaeological content, which integrates archaeology into a broader social context of use by connecting scholars, archaeological heritage professionals, and the wider public. More broadly, social media is transforming ways in which we perceive information, with its use becoming an increasingly important skill for researchers. This paper attempts to address issues of social media usage in digital archaeology through the case study of Lithuanian archaeology practices on Facebook. It provides an overview of Facebook use in archaeology by focusing on three core dimensions: users, content and communication, in attempt to understand the position of archaeological institutions and archaeologists, main types of shared archaeological content and criteria that enable successful communication  in social media.
article_title: Archaeology in social media: users, content and communication on Facebook

abstract: This in this paper we present a project that uses machine learning and classification techniques to assess the underlying structure of fictional literature in the eighteenth century and to relate this structure to a taxonomic system based on genre labels in titles.
article_title: The Cryptic Novel:  A Computational Taxonomy of the Eighteenth-Century Literary Field

abstract: This paper will argue that removing high-frequency, low-semantic weight words from topic models of poetry datasets improves the coherence of Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) topics and addresses reasonable concerns by some literary scholars that removing such language undercuts the methodology’s value as a mode of literary inquiry.  Exposing technical and theoretical decisions made while topic modeling 4,500 English language poems, this paper demonstrates how words such as “look” and “saw” remain influential and semantically present in document to topic distributions even when they have been removed during the data preparation process. Finally, it suggests that existing models of the poetic genre of ekphrasis, the verbal representation of visual representation, may be less dependent on poetic conventions once considered fundamental to the genre.
article_title: The Story of Stopwords: Topic Modeling an Ekphrastic Tradition

affiliation: Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media

abstract: The open-access, multimedia, peer-reviewed journal Southern Spaces will soon begin its tenth year. Published by the Emory University Libraries, Southern Spaces is an online-only journal of critical regional studies that takes as its subject the real and imagined spaces and places of the US South and their global connections. From its years of encouraging digital cultural empowerment as a strategy to transform scholarly publishing, Southern Spaces offers a case study for examining the effectiveness of a project intent upon increasing participation in the creation, dissemination, and curation of humanities scholarship. Given the entrenched commercial clout of conventional scholarly publishing and the slow-to-change institutional structures for tenure and promotion that still resist digital humanities scholarship, how can we assess the significance of this project of digital cultural empowerment? And how do the years of experience publishing Southern Spaces contribute to an understanding of broader movements of cultural critique and social change?
article_title: “Needless To Say”: Articulating Digital Publishing Practices as Strategies of Cultural Empowerment

abstract: In this paper, we will present a case study of how an ongoing, multi-faculty, interdisciplinary digital humanities project focused on the Susquehanna Valley in Pennsylvania has created, and continues to explore, ways in which students can excel both inside the classroom and outside. These DH projects involve undergraduates working with faculty, first in GIS registers and now in text-encoding and analysis environments on an unfolding expansive research project that affords otherwise unachievable opportunities for undergraduate student engagement, the development of new skills, and meaningful ongoing interaction between the institution and community that have, in turn, furthered the scope and scale of the project.
article_title: Digital learning in an undergraduate context: promoting long term student-faculty (and community) collaboration in the Susquehanna Valley, PA

abstract: To save Alan Liu's question of “Where is cultural criticism in the digital humanities?” from tendentiousness requires a richer, more precise account of the digital humanities as a set of material practices. To plan and enact a genuine partnership between the digital humanities and  (what Liu terms) “the mainstream humanities” requires intervening in these material practices through new ways of organizing and managing digital humanities work. We will discuss challenges that have arisen from a model of organizing work around “fellowships” (a structure inherited and adapted from the “mainstream humanities”) and we will highlight the creation and formulation of an alternative model, the Digital Humanities Incubator, that prizes long-term enrichment by all actors involved in the production of digital humanities work.
article_title: Making Digital Humanities Work

abstract: Because Whitman applied the title “Leaves of Grass” to more than ten distinctly different volumes, the goal of accurately tracing the book’s evolution has frustrated scholars. We have begun to experiment with distant reading strategies that provide views different from those offered by traditional critical opproaches. Such tools can begin to offer ways to assay and quantify some of the critical commonplaces that have grown up around Whitman’s masterwork. We have also been experimenting with a new way of visualizing textual phenomena and have created Indigo, an experimental XSLT-based tool to generate animated videos. Our experiment is in keeping with Whitman’s theories, in which “the reader . . . must himself or herself construct indeed the poem . . . .” In representing the literary work as an absorbing performance that comprises both "data" and "art," our work is, in the terms of Jerome McGann and Lisa Samuels, an act of “interpretive deformance.”
article_title: Leaves of Grass: Data Animation and XML Technologies

abstract: In this paper, we present a taxonomy that aims to make information relevant to digital humanities more easily discoverable. A transatlantic collaboration formed around this task that builds on earlier work such as the methods taxonomy of Arts-Humanities.net, its adaptation within the DARIAH project and the ad-hoc list of categories used by DiRT. We opened a draft version of the taxonomy for the public to comment on in September 2013 that received a huge amount of feedback from people around the globe and across the disciplines. This vivid discussion shows the relevance of this task that has been around the Digital Humanities ever since John Unsworth introduced his concept of 'scholarly primitives' in 2000. With this paper, we hope to continue that discussion. In three different scenarios that are based on the shared taxonomy, we present how it works to serve task and user-oriented endeavors.
article_title: Scholarly primitives revisited: towards a practical taxonomy of digital humanities research activities and objects

affiliation: Miami University, United States of America

abstract: This paper explores what I term "digital happiness": attempts to assess and maximize well-being using the theories of positive psychology and the methods of big data, sentiment analysis, crowdsourcing, social networking, the quantified self, and biometrics. This paper first provides an overview of these initiatives, demonstrating their efforts to track and triangulate individual internal emotional states, networked virtual data and connections, and real social relations and policies. I then position their rhetoric and ideology within the larger discourses of self-help, positive psychology, and utopian studies, and critically interrogate these projects’ utopian aspirations, analyzing their aims and methods for instantiating different ways of being and living, of creating both the happy person and the good society in the image of (and from the) raw data of individuals’ emotions.
article_title: Unhappy? There's an App for That: Digital Happiness, Data Mining, and Networks of Well-Being

affiliation: New York City College of Technology, CUNY

abstract: The project centered around the development of an encoding model for the Wandering Rocks episode. A custom XML markup using the TEI was developed for the episode. The project suggests that geoparsing and geocoding may be fulfilled by a mixture of automated, software-driven and manual, close reading based approaches. Interrogation of the encoded text reveals that the geoparsed text supports a number of critical frameworks regarding Ulysses in a quantitative, verifiable fashion.
article_title: Mapping and Unmapping Joyce: Geoparsing Wandering Rocks

affiliation: An Foras Feasa, National University of Ireland, Maynooth
Dept. of Computer Science, NUI Maynooth, Aja Teehan, Cognitive Corp

abstract: Starting from concepts like Rambo Ronais's "layered account" and  Geertz's "thick description", the proposal relies on the hypothesis that a "layered" representation of an electronic text can bring into light some aspects related to the production and circulation of meaning in the reading/interpretation and writing process. The study refers to models and methods like textual zoom, text network analysis and text summarisation and proposes a combined approach for structuring the text on "layers of meaning".
article_title: The Layered Text. From Textual Zoom, Text Network Analysis and Text Summarisation to a Layered Interpretation of Meaning

abstract: This presentation details the highly collaborative creation and facilitation of the University of Minnesota History Department's "How To Do History," course, and its transformation to "How To Do "Digital" History." Outlining both the process of designing and implementing the course, as well as showcasing work by the undergraduates who took the course, our presentation joins a chorus of scholars considering the crucial, if still under-represented, place of undergraduate pedagogy and digital humanities.
article_title: "How To Do (Digital) History" and Undergraduate Digital Humanities

abstract: This paper addresses two questions: how do readers use social media to express the value and the pleasure of reading for them, and what kinds of methods are most useful for analysing this kind of data so as to cast light on the phenomenology of reading experiences? This paper will present the findings of a project on developing methods for analysing and evaluating literary engagement in digital contexts, reporting on what can be learnt from the large amount of user-generated data available on microblogging services and social network sites, and evaluating the various analytical tools and methods available to scholars.
article_title: The social pleasure of the text: Applying digital humanities methods to reception studies
Problems in Modeling Transactions

affiliation: Wheaton College, Norton, Massachusetts, United States of America
Northeastern University, United States of America

abstract: Contrasting digital studies programs in the United States and the Middle East highlight the impact of digitization, open access and digital collaboration on not only cultures of the users in these and other areas, but also the traditional scholarly culture. Early Islamic and Christian manuscripts offer invaluable opportunities to understand and analyze the transfer of mathematics, science and history through ancient texts. Digitization, online scholarship and open sharing offer opportunity for broader access to manuscripts that are at increased risk in some libraries in the Middle East, offering free access to citizens and scholars. This open access empowers digital study by scholars and the public in the region and around the globe, while challenging traditional proprietary manuscript research and institutional traditions of protected access and exclusive study.
article_title: When Kidnapping is but One Risk: Digital Studies Challenge Scholarly and Regional Cultures

affiliation: Schoenberg Institute for Manuscript Studies, University of Pennsylvania

abstract: In this paper we test the hypothesis that authorial style depends on genre and find that the stylistic signatures of authors do indeed vary significantly, even when only considering the most frequent function words. We test this hypothesis by comparing the out-of-sample predictions of three different multinomial logistic regression models. We discuss our findings with regard to stylistic variation at the level of words and in the context of existing knowledge about literary genres in the Classical Age. We conclude by advocating adding logistical regression to the stylometric toolbox as a flexible way to investigate how authors' writing varies depending on context.
article_title: Progress Through Regression. Modeling Style across Genre in French Classical Theater

abstract: Authors present two rearrangements of the framing structure of SignWriting, a graphical system for Sign Languages, aimed at: 1) facilitating its learning; and 2) improving its computerization (in particular in relation to the proprietary software OGR and SWift))
article_title: Riorganizzare SignWriting per favorire la ricerca linguistica sulle Lingue dei Segni

abstract: The concept of transcriptional implicature is proposed as a way of accounting for common practices in transcription while also making sense of  variations in practice.  The formal model implicit in default transcriptional implicature can be elaborated in different ways to reflect a number of common variations in transcription practice which have hitherto eluded precise description in formal terms. We regard the formalization of transcription as an essential step towards formalizing the semantics of colloquial XML vocabularies like TEI.
article_title: Transcriptional implicature:  a contribution to markup semantics

affiliation: Black Mesa Technologies LLC, United States of America

abstract: The Digital Humanities Lab of the University of Basel has developed a workflow for migration-less preservation of digital data on optical media called “Monolith”. It combines the advantages of photographic material and standard digital imaging technology to create a long-term migration-less archiving system. This is achieved by the hybrid characteristics of the optical carrier. Any arbitrary binary bit stream is put right besides human readable technical, structural, and contextual metadata. Original files of any appropriate format are stored on film as visual 2D barcodes. This process can be regarded as a materialisation of binary data, which becomes visual and physical. Monolith has no limitation regarding the format of the file to be archived, it doesn't need migration and it doesn't need energy to transport information to the future.
article_title: Monolith: Materialised Bits, the Digital Rosetta Film

abstract: This paper describes a computer-enabled approach to exploring the presence, circulation and reception of fiction in Australian newspapers that enables research, and advances arguments, relevant to bibliographical, book historical and literary studies as well as digital humanities.
article_title: Mining a 'Trove': Modelling a Transnational Literary Culture

abstract: This paper aims at presenting TheofPhilo-Thesaurus of Philosophy, the prototype of a digital multilingual thesaurus in the field of Philosophy. With ‘thesaurus’ we mean a concept-based collection of terms that we are building by means of texts and philosophical dictionaries. We are testing TheofPhilo building up an ontology, which is finalized to semantic enrichment and to information retrieval in the digital resources uploaded by CNR-ILIESI in the portal Daphnet. Digital Archives of PHilosophical Texts on the NET .
article_title: TheofPhilo. A prototype for a Thesaurus of Philosophy

affiliation: CNR- Istituto per il Lessico Intellettuale Europeo e Storia delle Idee
CNR- Istituto per il Lessico Intellettuale Europeo e Storia delle Idee

article_title: Sequence, Tree and Graph at the Tip of Your Java Classes

abstract: La contribution vise à présenter un dispositif technopédagogique développé depuis 2011 dans le cadre d'un enseignement en Sciences du langage (analyse de conversations quotidiennes). Le dispositif en question prend la forme d'une interface web rassemblant dans un même espace de consultation et d'édition des données hétérogènes (source audio-visuelle, transcription de la source, divers commentaires métatextuels théoriques ou analytiques). Un tel dispositif facilite la constitution collaborative et émergente de bases de données orales et ainsi interroge le rapport des Humanités Digitales à l'enseignement et à la recherche.
article_title: IMPACT : un dispositif de transcription et de commentaire de l'oral, pour l'enseignement et la recherche
keywords: TIC pour l'enseignement et la recherche

abstract: This paper introduces the preliminary results of my research into using "MARY" text-to-speech software to automatically determine poetic rhythm. My approach is to extract and analyse data from intermediate stages of MARY's natural language processing, in order to predict where the beats will fall when the poem is performed or read, and the patterns of sound that this effects. My results demonstrate the validity of this approach, which will soon be rolled out onto the the broad canon of English poetry. Such quantitative analysis will enable me to arrive at a richer and more comprehensive account of developments in poetic form and rhythm. In bringing both new methods and new material into consideration the project has the potential to re-write the history of English poetic form, and of poetic influence, altogether.
article_title: Mining poetic rhythm: using text-to-speech software to rewrite English literary history

abstract: This paper demonstrates a technique for building a directed weighted network from the co-occurrence of saints in medieval artwork.  The directed network is used to infer the prestige of saints from 1230 to circa 1320.  The results point to several trends including an increase in the popularity of female saints after 1300.
article_title: Mining the Cloud of Witness: Inferring the Prestige of Saints from Medieval Paintings

abstract: This paper will investigate the problems associated with traditional spatiotemporal visualisations of historical data. It will examine our own comprehension of time and space and how understanding their vagueness, ambiguities and uncertainties are important when it comes to visualising and modelling changes in their components. Using data from the 1641 Depositions (testimonies documenting the experiences of witnesses of the 1641 Irish rebellion), a spatiotemporal visualisation is created to illustrate the difficulties in using historical information for this process.
article_title: The Problem of Time and Space: The Difficulties in Visualising Spatiotemporal Change in Historical Data

abstract: As widespread interest in the Open Data movement has grown in recent years  some museums from all over the world have started to share and provide their digital content with Internet users. These new practices not only involve users’ interest and traffic increase on museums websites but also magnify the institutional transparency which provokes a different conception of the museum authority. Then, we can find different ways of making available to explore and download high resolution photographs or exhibition catalogues as well as more complex procedures as open APIs development in order to allow users to create their own application based on museums data.
article_title: Open content production in museums. A discourse and critical analysis of the museum in the digital age

abstract: We introduce an approach for disambiguating end-of-line hyphenated words in French based on the given text and an external dictionary. Compared to the obvious way to handle hyphenation automatically our approach has reduced the number of falsely guessed spellings for a tested set of French texts by at least the factor of 1.5. In particular, the approach helps to reduce the effort of manually determining the correct spellings dramatically by focusing on the few cases where the approach is not reliable.
article_title: On automatically disambiguating end-of-line hyphenated words in French texts

affiliation: Institute of Computer Science, Martin-Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg, Germany
Institute of Romance Studies, Martin-Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg, Germany
Institute of Computer Science, Martin-Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg, Germany

abstract: CollateX is a tool that computes a Text Variant Graph in form of a static, horizontally aligned, directed acyclic graph (DAG) with vertices showing the various text fragments and edges labeled with edition identifiers connecting subsequent text fragments. The tool Stemmaweb extends the CollateX graph to allow for user-driven annotation and modification of the graph structure (e.g., merging and splitting of vertices). Despite the attached interaction capabilities, it seems that there is little value put on designing the graphs. The purpose of this paper is to raise awareness for improving the readability for Text Variant Graphs. We propose a list of design rules for styling the graph, and its vertices and edges to facilitate a rapid comprehension of the underlying alignment structure by the user.
article_title: 5 Design Rules for Visualizing Text Variant Graphs

affiliation: Image and Signal Processing Group, Institute for Computer Science, Leipzig University, Germany
Göttingen Centre for Digital Humanities, University of Göttingen, Germany
Göttingen Centre for Digital Humanities, University of Göttingen, Germany
Image and Signal Processing Group, Institute for Computer Science, Leipzig University, Germany

abstract: Panel overview
article_title: A Large Database Approach to Cultural History

abstract: Semi-automated extraction of details corresponding to narratological fabula (raw events) from a corpus of witness statements provides the decontextualized building blocks for identifying narratives that transverse a corpus. This paper describes a framework for assembling those blocks into transversal narratives. Storygraph, our tool, is a novel expansion of parallel-axes coordinate plots that shows the movement of people through the spatiotemporal context of a corpus in a manner agnostic to the source document. This method allows for the emergence of narratives that go beyond the boundaries of one interview. In the context of 503 World Trade Center Task Force Interviews, this technique makes manifest narratives of those who did not testify, but were observed by others who did. These assembled narratives, in cases like Chief Ganci, can reveal stories of those who did not survive. Future work will look at larger spatiotemporal frames, larger corpora, and more diverse violations ecologies.
article_title: Visualizing Computational, Transversal Narratives from the World Trade Towers

affiliation: Departments of English and Communication, Georgia State University
Department of Computer Science, Georgia State University
Department of English, Georgia State University

abstract: The Kinomatics Project is a multidisciplinary study of the industrial geometry of culture focussing in particular (but not exclusively) on the cinema. The project results from both the recent digitisation of the cinema industries as well as contemporary research practices in the discipline (Verhoeven, 2012). The researchers have collated a unique dataset of global cinema showtimes which alone, and in combination with additional datasets, challenge many of the unspoken assumptions and ordinary practices of conventional film studies research.
article_title: Kinomatics: big cultural data and the study of cinema

abstract: In this contribution we present a pedagogical approach with the intention to introduce digital humanities to undergraduate students. Our approach may be regarded from three angles: first, as the construction of tailored toolkits of digital methods for students; second, as a contribution to the analysis of material properties of cultural productions, and; third, as a mid-term strategy to orient students toward design-based learning techniques.
article_title: Introducing digital humanities through the analysis of cultural productions
Advocating for a Digital Humanities Curriculum: Design and Implementation

abstract: The close examination of typefaces is an area of Humanities research that is difficult and time consuming. Accordingly, few scholars have had the inclination or resources to dedicate to this field of study. The Early Modern OCR Project underway at the Initiative for Digital Humanities, Media, and Culture at Texas A&M University is making use of historical typography research as a way of improving the OCR process for early modern printed documents. Our Book History team in Texas A&M University’s Cushing Memorial Library and Archives is closely examining printed documents of the early 17th century to identify the differences between two categories of typeface. Their work has been greatly aided by a tool created for the eMOP project. This tool has the potential to change the methods and time requirements for font type research.
article_title: Book History and Software Tools: Examining Typefaces for OCR Training in eMOP

abstract: The Early Modern OCR Project (eMOP) at the Initiative for Digital Humanities, Media, and Culture (IDHMC) is in the middle of a 2-year grant-funded project to scan the approximately 45 million page images that make up the Eighteenth Century Collections Online (ECCO) and Early English Books Online (EEBO) collections. We are finding however, that many page images are of such poor quality that they require some kind of pre-processing before they can be successfully OCR'd.  The eMOP team, along with collaborators from the University of Illinois and Texas A&M University, are creating a post-processing workflow which will allow us to use OCR output to programmatically identify problems that exist in our input page images. This will allow to then apply the appropriate pre-processing to those poor quality page images to produce effective results when those page images are re-OCR'd.
article_title: Diagnosing Page Image Problems with Post-OCR Triage for eMOP

abstract: This paper is focused on the methodology applied to the development of components in the domain of collaborative philology for the Memorata Poetis Project. The initiative, led by the University of Venice, coordinates eight units sharing the same cyber-infrastructure and is co-funded by the Italian Ministry of Instruction, University and Research (PRIN 2010/11). Firstly, we will introduce the overall modelling of the philology domain from a logical point of view. Secondly, we will discuss the engineering methods for analysis of the required components. Finally, we will describe the application of the aforementioned methodology to the specific part of the project developed in Pisa.
article_title: A top-down approach to the design of components for the philological domain

abstract: This paper describes the creation of a poetic ontology in order to use it as a basis to link the different databases and projects working on metrics and poetry. It is built on the model of the Spanish digital repertoire ReMetCa, but its aim is to be enlarged and improved in order to fit under every poetic system. The conceptual semantic model, written in OWL, includes classes and metadata from standard ontological models related to humanities fields (such as CIDOC or Dublin Core), and adds specific elements and properties to describe poetic phenomena. Its final objective is to interconnect, reuse and locate data disseminated through poetic repertoires, in order to boost interoperability among them.
article_title: Building a metrical ontology as a model to link digital poetic repertoires

affiliation: Universidad Nacional de Educación Distancia, España
Universidad Nacional de Educación Distancia, España
Universidad Nacional de Educación Distancia, España

abstract: This paper reflects on the concepts of text and modelling to show how objects of analysis and strategy of analysis in Digital Humanities (thereafter DH) research (and teaching) have expanded our boundaries of what is knowledgeable, while at the same time creating other limitations. The authors identify such limitations both at the epistemological level - e.g. the adoption of formalisations that impose a rigid structure on slippery and rich objects of analysis - as well as the linguistic level - e.g. the uncritical adoption of terminology belonging to the domain of computer sciences. The idea of ‘pragmatic modelling’ is therefore proposed as a strategy for research and teaching in DH: the definition of a sort of middle-out approach (halfway between top down and bottom up) that combines formal and experimental modelling techniques with a constructive use of language. Reflections on metaphorical reasoning will be used to exemplify this approach in practice.
article_title: Circling around texts and language: towards ‘pragmatic modelling’ in Digital Humanities

affiliation: Lessico Intellettuale Europeo e Storia delle Idee

abstract: Digital research data created and used in research in the Humanities is often available only during and shortly after the funding period of the given research project. The National Data Curation and Service Center for Digital Research Data in the Humanities will provide the infrastructuree and service to guarantee the permanent access to primary research data after project fundings ceased.
article_title: National Data Curation and Service Center for Digital Research Data in the Humanities

affiliation: Digital Humanities Lab / University of Basel
Digital Humanities Lab / University of Basel

abstract: This paper describes techniques how textual expert data and spatial data can be linked. It presents a generic software, which enables humanities research in small 3D spatial areas.This software is employed in a case study, that aims to analyse and correlate the spatial contexts of a late gothic church and its interior.
article_title: Relating texts to 3D-information: A generic software environment for Spatial Humanities

affiliation: Akademie der Wissenschaften und der Literatur Mainz

abstract: This talk describes a simple method for extracting cultural models from textual source materials using ideas and resources accessible to students and researchers in the digital humanities. The method is described in the context of three digital humanities projects. The goal of the talk is to propose an approach to the use of quantitative methods in the humanities that does not alienate the researcher from the tools of interpretation.
article_title: Common Container Correlation: A Simple Method for the Extraction of Structural Models from Statistical Data

abstract: The concept of potential criticism addresses many key challenges and issues involving cultural empowerment and critical analysis  in the digital humanities. Shannon Clute and I developed and applied the concept of potential criticism in our 2011 book, The Maltese Touch of Evil: Film Noir and Potential Criticism. Potential criticism, inspired by the work of the Oulipo and recombinatory poetics, is a methodological approach to textual analysis that uses pre-determined mathematical or algorithmic constraints to generate new data sets out of any corpora of digital texts and objects, whether they are alphabetic, visual, or time-based. This paper argues for the broader applicability of potential criticism throughout the digital humanities, since constrained and algorithmic methodologies can be used on any kind of digital text, including video and film, to generate new and unexpected arrangements of data to spur scholarly investigations and discoveries.
article_title: Potential Criticism in the Digital Humanities

abstract: Categorization mechanisms in many digital media systems such as social networks and videogames are inadequate for representing the complexities of many social identity phenomena. To address such limitations, we built the Chimeria system - a platform built around a dynamic computational model of identity and more flexible group membership dynamics. Chimeria allows for the authoring of narrative experiences that parallel phenomena observed in real world social groups, like the notion of membership gradience and individuals shifting both within and between social groups. Our aim is to allow authors to make use of Chimeria 's underlying model to construct their own narratives pertaining to multiple types of group membership or identity related issues such as discrimination or marginalization. By granting control over the visual appearance, interaction mechanisms, and narrative content, we hope authors will use the platform along with their constructed narratives for both critical analysis and creative expression.
article_title: The Chimeria Platform: User Empowerment through Expressing Social Group Membership Phenomena

affiliation: Comparative Media Studies Program, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Comparative Media Studies Program, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Comparative Media Studies Program, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

abstract: The Victorian author Charles Dickens collaborated with his younger contemporary Wilkie Collins on a number of stories, typically for the Christmas Numbers of his journals: Household Words and All the Year Round . While some of their collaborative pieces were written with the assistance of other 'salaried staff writers' including Elizabeth Gaskell, Adelaide Anne Proctor, et al., four works are known to have been co-authored by Dickens and Collins alone (Nayder, 2002). These collaborative writings vary in design and style from one another as well as in theme and setting. In some cases, one chapter can be read as radically different from another due to the varying proportion of contribution by each of the duo. The present study applies stylometric techniques in an effort to detect stylistic shifts in the collaborations of Dickens and Collins. The results of this study present internal evidence of how the two authors were 'unequally partnered' with each other.
article_title: Stylometry of Collaborations: Dickens, Collins and their collaborative writings

abstract: This paper investigates how digital mapping tools present students and readers of literature with an unprecedented ability to map fictional spaces in their own liking and how these various representations can influence our understanding of and relationship with literary works. Typically thought of as a tool to assist the user in finding a certain location, when used to identify fictional spaces, maps possess the power to convey societal and cultural ideologies. In recent scholarship, there has been a growing interest in the interplay between maps and narrative. “Story maps,” “fictional cartography,” and “geospatial storytelling” are some of the terms utilized to describe the relationship between place and space (Caquard). Our paper takes the current discussion of the connection between narrative and space to another plane by exploring the exchange between fictional spaces and narrative as represented by maps.
article_title: A Sense of Place: Mapping Fictional Landscapes in Literary Narratives

affiliation: University of California, Los Angeles, US
University of California, Los Angeles, US
University of California, Los Angeles, US

abstract: This paper presents the methodology, workflow, and findings of an interdisciplinary project, "Humanities on the Z-Axis," based at the University of Victoria. Through a combination of techniques in three-dimensional fabrication, geospatial mapping, speculative computing, and pattern analysis, z-axis research expresses the geospatial narratives of modernist novels by first geo-referencing them and then using that geo-data to deform base layers of historical maps. The output of the research includes warped, 3D maps of cities central to modernist literary production. These maps can be viewed as 3D models on a screen or as physical prototypes in hand, and they are deformed using geo-data drawn from novels by Djuna Barnes, James Joyce, and Jean Rhys, among others. Ultimately, they show scholars how modernist authors wrote the city, and findings suggest that they contradict existing research in modernist studies about how, exactly, cities are represented in modernist novels.
article_title: Z-Axis Scholarship: Modeling How Modernists Write the City

abstract: Many have argued that the digital humanities is about building stuff and sharing stuff -- that the digital humanities reframes the work we do in the humanities as less consumptive and more curatorial, less solitary and more collaborative. I maintain, though, that the digital humanities is about breaking stuff. Especially at the undergraduate level, this is the work of the digital humanities that most needs doing. In my undergraduate digital humanities course, the first assignment has students break something as an act of literary criticism. This paper expands upon a brief article I wrote about this assignment, exploring the new pedagogies that the digital humanities demand and give rise to.
article_title: Digital Pedagogy is about Breaking Stuff

affiliation: University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States of America

keywords: digital humanities - pedagogy and curriculum Keywords: Pedagogy

abstract: The Macro-Etymological Analyzer (http://jonreeve.com/etym) is a web app designed to compute the etymological origins of each word in a text, tally them and categorize them by origin language family. This paper describes the program and a series of experiments in digital literary analysis that employ the program. Analyses of works by Joyce, Woolf, and Whitman are discussed.
article_title: Macro-Etymological Textual Analysis

affiliation: New York University, United States of America

abstract: Most digital libraries are made available not only to researchers in a certain Humanities domain (e.g. classical philologists, historians, historical linguists), but also to common users. This fact has posited new requirements to the functionalities offered by the Digital Libraries, and thus imposed the usage of methods from Language Technology for content analysis and content presentation in a form understandable to the end user. Language technology tools are mostly adapted in order to make corpus linguistics research but not really used as means for text processing. One of the main barriers is the text readability in terms of language style and terms. The aim of this paper, describing on-going work is to demonstrate that multilingual aspects in historical texts are a big challenge but can serve also for building a knowledge-based to be used in text presentation.
article_title: Less explored multilingual issues in the automatic processing of historical texts – a case study

abstract: Como respuesta al tema al que nos invita el la Conferencia Anual Digital Humanities 2014 (Digital Cultural Empowerment), me propongo explorar de qué modo el digital turn, que ha traído consigo un nuevo modelo de sociedad, economía, cultura, y un nuevo orden epistemológico (esto es, nuevos modos de producción, narrativización, distribución y consumo del conocimiento), está propiciando: una redefinición de los valores que hasta ahora habían primado en la definición de los objetos de la cultura en el ámbito disciplinar de la Historia del Arte; nuevos procesos de asignación de valor; y por tanto, nuevas modalidades de canonización.
article_title: Canon, value and artistic culture: critical inquiry about the new processes of assigning value in the digital realm

abstract: The process of concept forming remains unsolved and has become a challenging issue in humanities research. The panel’s theme, “Idea, Event and Action: The Digital Humanities Study of the Concept Formation in Modern China”, mainly focuses on analysis of humanities topic by digital technology approach. The common objective on this panel’s studies is to describe concept forming process of modern China in a global and efficient way, by using digital technology and statistical method incorporate in humanities perspective.
article_title: Ideas, Events and Actions: The Digital Humanity Study of the Concept Formation in Modern China

abstract: Existing historical linguistic corpora vary a with respect to formats, corpus architecture, annotation types, values and preparation steps. The LAUDATIO-Repository (www.laudatio-repository.org) provides an open access environment to facilitate the management of such heterogeneous research data with an extensive, uniform and structured documentation and a facetted and free-text search without constraints such as formats or annotations. To this purpose, we developed a meta-model which is expressive enough to represent a large variety of corpus formats. This meta-model, described as a TEI-ODD specification (Burnard & Rahtz 2004), is also the basis for the technical implementation in the repository.
article_title: Modeling Linguistic Research Data for a Repository for Historical Corpora
keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: For under-researched fields within the Humanities there is a clear need of combining different approaches (large-scale next to small-scale), connecting different kinds of tools (databases and text edition/analysis), linking different levels of data (data - metadata) and engaging into collaboration people differently concerned by the research (professionals and volunteers). European women's literary history (until the early 20th century) is considered as being such an under-researched field. In this contribution we will present two case studies illustrating the importance and potentialities of this kind of large, diversified approach. We will also highlight the practical problems they provide, which for the moment are still creating obstacles. We will discuss these obstacles, addressing in particular the gaps between the technological possibilities, the willingness of potential volunteers (in our case often women: those whom we want to empower by our research) and the academic system. We will also propose possible strategies.
article_title: Digitizing Women’s Literary History: The Possibility Of Collaborative Empowerment?

affiliation: Huygens ING - Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences, Netherlands
Huygens ING - Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences, Netherlands
Huygens ING - Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences, Netherlands

abstract: While digitizing large textual corpora seems to require a trade, quantity for quality, and to promote sloppy archiving and superficial reading, when working with early modern texts, more care is required to make the texts findable and readable than is typically given over the normal course of reading. The Early Modern Optical Character Recognition Project has built a "scholar-sourced" metadata correction and transcription tool that, if used widely by experts and citizen scholars, could give us better access to high quality materials published between 1473 and 1800 than we have yet been able to achieve, helping us find documents we did not know existed.
article_title: Distributed “Forms of Attention”:  eMOP and the Cobre Tool

affiliation: Texas A&M University, United States of America
Texas A&M University, United States of America
Texas A&M University, United States of America
Texas A&M University, United States of America

abstract: At HyperStudio, we are investigating how digital tools can encourage discovery and serendipity in the humanities, with a focus on art objects and museum collections. For this short paper session, we propose to share our research on the process of discovery, assessing algorithms used in research and recommendation tools on both scholarship and industry platforms. We will survey existing projects that allow scholars and casual users alike to discover new art. We will also discuss how we plan to incorporate this research as we develop ArtX, a tool that will empower users to discover cultural events, exhibitions, and art objects in the Boston area.
article_title: Rethinking Recommendations: Digital Tools for Art Discovery

affiliation: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States of America
Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States of America

abstract: This presentation will demonstrate a UCLA software project entitled ClipNotes, a collaborative, XML-based Windows/iPad app project that facilitates quick annotation, segmentation and presentation of film clips. The design of ClipNotes is deceptively simple: it allows users to mark up video files with metadata in easily-produced XML files that when connected to a video file, allow for precise, granular analysis that is easily disseminated and presented. All XML files are archived in a public database, which allows for widespread sharing of textual analysis and provides an invaluable teaching resource. Examples will be shown of traditional textual analysis amplified by software, as well as a demonstration of how ClipNotes can be integrated into the classroom, allowing students to contribute to an open-access database. ClipNotes demonstrates how software applications can be utilized to enact detailed analysis, archive and disseminate insights, and welcome students into the sphere of knowledge production.
article_title: ClipNotes: Digital Annotation and Data­Mining for Film & Television Analysis

affiliation: University of California, Los Angeles, United States of America

abstract: If a vocabulary-based authorial attribution technique fails to attribute an original text and a pastiche to different authors, ``is this because the pastiche is good, or because the technique is faulty" (Somers and Tweedie, 2003)? I use this question to critically explore (1) the present lack of theory to account for an algorithm's effectiveness at identifying authorship and style, (2) the theoretical interdependence of these as exhibited exemplified by concepts such as quality . Identifying an ambiguity in Somers and Tweedie's original question, I reframe the question using a scheme from R. G. Collingwood’s “On the So-Called Idea of Causation.” This allows me to parse the original ambiguity in Somers and Tweedie’s question into several logically distinct classes. This parsing suggests that attributing the success or failure of authorship attribution algorithms to only algorithm _effectiveness_ or pastiche _quality_ effectively equates two incommensurable ontological systems as if they were logically consistent.
article_title: Incommensurability? Authorship, Style, and the Need for Theory

abstract: A diagnosis and polemic, this essay uses a topic model of literary studies journals to show that literary studies has been characterized by a major turn towards the subject matter of social science. It then argues that topic modeling itself should be considered as a form of sociological content analysis, an aggregative method and not a novel hermeneutic. And this is a good thing: let DH embrace the social sciences.
article_title: Let DH Be Sociological! [Short Paper]

abstract: This paper discusses the large research project Translantis, which uses text mining technologies to analyze “big data” repositories of public media. The projects uses cultural text mining, i.e., mining of cultural aspects of entities and events, in order to address macro-historical questions such as the emergence of transnational reference cultures. The challenge is to develop a tool for cultural text mining that enables scholars to systematically search very large quantities of textual data in a reliable and reproducible way.
article_title: Cultural text mining: using text mining to map the emergence of transnational reference cultures in public media repositories

abstract: The tools described in this presentation allow the publication and maintenance of premodern Chinese text through a network of text repositories. The repositories are maintained in a GitHub-like way, thus allowing users to fork text and use merge request to update a canonical, authorative version of the texts. The texts in these repositories are accessed through a desktop tool named Mandoku , which serves as a central scholarly workbench while transparently allowing access to the repositories. Both tools are developed and enhanced through a community driven development process that tries to engage scholars and developers on an equal footing.
article_title: Kanripo and Mandoku: Tools for git-based distributed repositories for premodern Chinese texts

abstract: This paper discusses the idea of a 'digital heuristic'. In part one we illustrate the concept's relevance in the context of heureCLÉA, a BMBF-funded eHumanities project in which two research teams (one computer scientists, the second narratologists) focus on an exemplary hermeneutic “use case”: the decoding of temporal information in narratives. Here, the goal is to develop a heuristic plug-in solution for our text annotation and analysis tool CATMA in order to support both the tagging and the interpretation of narrative time information. Against this backdrop part two of this paper reflects upon the idea of a digital heuristic in more general terms. We believe that the concept per se points us to the digital humanities' methodological challenge to “push back the boundary” of interpretation in a critically reflected manner.
article_title: Pushing Back the Boundary of Interpretation: Concept, Practice and Relevance of a Digital Heuristic
Literary Canon and Digital Bibliographies: The Case of the United States

abstract: The desire to reveal the history all around us, to see into the past, is as old as civilization. With the emergence of augmented reality (AR) technology, historians and public humanities professionals are exploring new ways to research, teach and learn about the past. In this paper the authors reflect on the design, development and testing of two location-based AR applications, and propose best practices for using AR to enrich our understanding of history, and support the cultural empowerment of citizens. In part one of the paper, the authors make conclusions about best practices for AR design and development with a focus on two iPhone applications. In part two, the authors provide a preliminary report on the testing of these apps. In part three, the authors speculate about the ways in which Google Glass will transform digital humanists' use of augmented reality for cultural empowerment.
article_title: History All Around Us: Towards Best Practices for Augmented Reality for Public History and Cultural Empowerment

abstract: This paper describes a new method for limiting the words to be used in a computational text-analysis to those that occur at widely varied frequencies. The new method, CoV Tuning, uses the coefficient of variation, a well-known measure of dispersion, along with the number of texts in the analysis in which the word appears, to "tune" the word frequency list in an attempt to improve the analysis of textual similarity and difference. The coefficient of variation is defined as the standard deviation of the frequencies of a word in a set of samples divided by its average frequency in the same samples and multiplied by 100. The method is tested on several diverse sets of texts to show that CoV Tuning works significantly better than the standard word frequency list.
article_title: Tuning the Word Frequency List

affiliation: New York University, United States of America

abstract: This paper takes chapter 1 of Stephen Ramsay's Reading Machines , "An Algorithmic Criticism" as its point of departure. Ramsay complains that computational approaches to literature lack "bold statements, strong readings, and broad generalizations," and that this helps to explain why computational approaches have not had much influence on literary study. Computational approaches, he says, have been too cautious, to tied to a (pseudo) scientific approaches to interest literary critics, who tend to want to open texts up to new interpretations rather than to solve problems. He begins an algorithmic approach to Virginia Woolf's The Waves in an attempt to model what he sees as a bolder, more provocative, freer kind of computational literary study. This paper reveals some drawbacks of Ramsay's approach, some problems in his algorithmic provocation, and some ways in which a more careful and rigorous approach can provide more insight into Woolf's novel.
article_title: Making Waves: Algorithmic Criticism Revisited

affiliation: New York University, United States of America

abstract: This presentation will investigate K-Rad character substitutions as they were utilized in serialized ASCII text publications during the 1980s and 1990s. These text files, influenced by a genealogy of informational manuals on the topics of hacking and phreaking, sought to take writing beyond transparent signification, imposing hackerly techniques on to the text itself, by extending, disrupting, and hypermediating codes of discourse. In conventional informational writing, disruption and hypermediation are considered to impede signification; in K-Rad texts, they become key signifying agents. K-Rad writing attempts to push boundaries, to present the unpresentable, and to break all codes, whether legal, moral, linguistic, or typographic. At the 2014 Digital Humanities Conference, I will present a series of K-Rad ASCII text files, demonstrating a sequence of increasingly baroque substitutions and suggesting conceptual reading practices that we might use to engage with these early avant-garde digital texts.
article_title: \/\/ÆΓÑing: A Conceptual Parsing of ASCII Character Substitutions

abstract: The present paper describes and implements the semantic analysis of analogy and metaphor in large textual corpora, using the recently-completed database of the _Historical Thesaurus of English_ (published in 2009 as the _Historical Thesaurus of the Oxford English Dictionary_). Using semantic annotation techniques and log-likelihood measures on a 600,000 word corpus of abstract popular science (including a mathematical exposition of number theory, a physics text on parallel universes, and two books on string and quantum theory), the paper digitally demonstrates the existence and the extent of significant analogical content in this corpus. In so doing, it applies Franco Moretti’s ‘distant reading’ programme in the analysis of literary history to non-narrative texts, as well as continuing work on integrating meaning into the methodologies of corpus linguistics.
article_title: Metaphor, Popular Science and Semantic Tagging: Distant Reading with the Historical Thesaurus of English

abstract: The CURIOS project explores how digital archives for rural community heritage groups can be made more sustainable so that volunteer members can maintain a lasting digital presence. It is developing software tools to help remote rural communities to collaboratively maintain and present information about their cultural heritage. The objective is to investigate the use of semantic web/linked data technology to build a general, flexible and “future proof” software platform that could help such projects to develop digital archives and to be sustainable over time. As an interdisciplinary project we aim to synthesise a narrative that draws from both social science and computer science perspectives by critically reflecting upon the novel approach taken and the on-going results that are being produced.
article_title: CURIOS: Connecting and Empowering Community Heritage through Linked Data

abstract: In this long paper we will be looking at the fact that many digital resources are somewhat incomplete in the sense that, due to legal, technical and economical reasons, it is still very rare for an entire run of a resource to be made available digitally online. We will discuss what strategies there are to represent gaps in a digital collection, how to make the choices that have led to these gaps more transparent and also what consequences this entails for the scholar who is working with a digital collection. The Europeana Newspapers project, which is creating full-text and a common online platform for 10m pages of digitised newspapers from 12 libraries across Europe, will serve us as an example in this investigation.
article_title: Representation and Absence in Digital Resources: The Case of Europeana Newspapers

affiliation: The KB National Library of the Netherlands, Netherlands

abstract: In our paper we follow the distant reading method (Moretti 2005 , Moretti 2013) focusing on the phenomenon of naïve poetry – poetical opuses, composed by non-professional poets and distributed on special web-sites. We compare a corpora of Russian naive poetry with Russian Poetic corpus, which presents Russian poetical classics from the 18th century till the early 1930th. We look first of all at frequency measures in both resources and analyze the revealing fluctuations of different word frequencies. Then we make a qualitative analysis of the nouns that occur in the top 100 of each frequency list. We identify a range of semantic domains that can be expressed by these nouns and compare the domains of each poetical resource. As a result we define three main strategies of naïve composition: the imitative strategy , the self-actualization strategy and the extensive strategy .
article_title: Distant reading of naïve poetry: corpora comparison as research methodology

affiliation: National Research Unversity Higher School of Economics Moscow, Russian Federation
National Research Unversity Higher School of Economics Moscow, Russian Federation

abstract: How have text analysis tools in the humanities been imagined in the past? What did humanities computing developers think they were addressing with now dated technologies like punch cards, printed concordances and verbose command languages? Whether the analytic functionality is at the surface, as with Voyant Tools, or embedded at deeper levels, as with the Lucene-powered searching and browsing capabilities of the Old Bailey, the web-based text analysis tools that we use today are very different from the first tentative technologies developed by computing humanists. Following Siegfried Zieliniski's exploration of forgotten media technologies, this paper will look at three forgotten text analysis technologies and how they were introduced by their developers at the time.
article_title: Towards an Archaeology of Text Analysis Tools

abstract: Our approach presents a novel concept for data federation tailored to the arts and humanities from a holistic perspective. Focusing on the needs of research projects, interdisciplinary and broad use-cases, we especially address the reusability of explicated knowledge on correlations between schemata and digital collections and show where domain experts are required to bridge semantic gaps. Although we primarily focus the facilitation of a combined broad and deep search with a virtual, query-time integration, the proposed concept also addresses requirements of a materialized integration of research data on granularity levels required by focused disciplinary or interdisciplinary research projects . The three main topics that are being discussed are the evolution of semantic clusters which contain the reusable background knowledge, our use-case orientation and scalability considerations .
article_title: A novel approach for a reusable federation of research data within the arts and humanities
keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: Based on work done by Huitfeldt, Sperberg-McQueen, and Marcoux to develop a formal model of transcription, and by Caton as a result of this, the present paper elucidates six fundamental terms. The discussion aims both to clarify the existing work (and provide semantic constraints where none have been offered before) and to establish terms of reference for future work on the model of transcription (and related models).
article_title: Six terms fundamental to modelling transcription

abstract: The purpose of this paper is to explore the evolutionary dynamics of literary genre: the development of the 19th Century British novel is used as a motivating case study. The author constructs an agent-based model in NetLogo consisting of two interacting levels: (1) a genetic algorithm in which cultural forms (e.g., works of literature, pieces of music, etc.) are represented as binary feature strings. Cultural forms evolve across generations via asexual and sexual reproduction. Genres are represented as hierarchical clusters of similar feature strings. (2) Cultural forms are subjected to the selection pressure of consumer preferences. Preferences are heterogeneous: each consumer's tastes are represented by an ideal point in feature space. Preferences are configured in landscapes that vary in their levels of structure, entropy, and diversity. Landscapes are dynamic and may change due to (i) exogenous demographic shifts (e.g., population growth, generational turnover) or (ii) endogenous feedback (e.g., conformity / anti-conformity effects).
article_title: Simulating the Cultural Evolution of Literary Genres

affiliation: Columbia University, United States of America
Harvard University, United States of America
University of Florida, United States of America

abstract: The proposed talk will discuss the application of forensic computer science tools and methods to born digital documents and parts of archives, focusing on the philological benefit for genetic scholarly editions and the critique génétique on the one hand as well as on issues of sane archiving and representation of the digital record in a scholarly edition on the other. Exemplary subject matter of the inquiry will be a selection of recovered materials from harddrives in the Thomas Kling archive which represents the range of retrievable transitory 'genetic' textual material, e.g. recoverable documents, temporary files, memory fragments and several disk operation artifacts on multiple generations of operating systems. The harddrives have been forensically imaged for longterm preservation by the author of this paper and by a forensic laboratory recently, and it will be the first time these findings are being publicly discussed.
article_title: Harddrive Philology: Analysing the Writing Process on Thomas Kling's Archived Laptops

abstract: Narrative has become an active research focus in the artificial intelligence community in recent years, with efforts aimed at the construction of computational models for storytelling and story understanding. AI researchers often speak of narrative as its own form of intelligence—a complex cognitive phenomenon encompassing natural language understanding and generation, common-sense reasoning, analogical reasoning, planning, physical perception, imagination, and social cognition. Computational models of narrative draw upon a multitude of different techniques from the AI toolkit, ranging from detailed symbolic knowledge representation to large-scale statistical analyses. Our purpose in proposing this panel for DH2014 is two-fold. First, we want to introduce literary critics to parallel efforts underway in AI-narrative research and computational modeling. Second, we want to open a dialogue about the process for and implications of operationalizing canonical narrative theories, especially those from Russian Formalism and French Structuralism, for the computational analysis and generation of stories.
article_title: Computational Models of Narrative: Using Artificial Intelligence to Operationalize Russian Formalist and French Structuralist Theories

abstract: In the second phase of the Stanford Literary Lab’s multi-year ongoing project to create a system for detecting the formal features of poetry, we have focused our attention on the question of meter. Using a new method that combines a series of rule-based analyses with an iterative probabilistic-based classification algorithm, we can now detect, with a high degree of accuracy, both the meter and line length of individual poems. We have trained our algorithm to recognize individual metrical feet, such as iambs, dactyls, anapests, trochees, and spondees, and to combine these identifications with a signal-processing approach to the entire poem to classify the overall metrical scheme of any given poem. We have trained and tested our algorithm on a corpus of over 300,000 English language poems from the late medieval period to the twentieth century. We have also applied our algorithm to multi-lingual corpora, including German and French.
article_title: The Stanford Literary Lab Transhistorical Poetry Project Phase II: Metrical Form

affiliation: Stanford University, United States of America
Stanford University, United States of America
Stanford University, United States of America
Stanford University, United States of America
