Stanford University, United States of America

abstract: The Photogrammar project examines the "Farm Security Administration – Office of War Information" dataset of over 170,000 monochrome and colour photographs, commissioned between 1935 and 1945 by the government of the United States of America. The subject of a successful Digital Humanities Start-Up Grant from the US National Endowment for the Humanities, the project seeks to answer research questions that emerged from scholars at Yale University. Our paper will focus on three Digital Humanities techniques that we have used to analyze the corpus: 1) Geospatial: Computational derivation of latitude and longitude; 2) Text Mining: Vector-space analysis to expose thematic similarity; and 3) Statistical Analysis: Contextual inference to “re-discover” missing metadata.
article_title: Photogrammar: Organizing Visual Culture through Geography, Text Mining, and Statistical Analysis

affiliation: Yale University, United States of America
Yale University, United States of America

abstract: The research presented here illustrates that the potential for GIS and related technologies in the humanities goes beyond both mapping and distant reading. Specifically, we identify three general ways that geographical technologies can enrich our understanding of texts: first, distant reading using Geographical Text Analysis (GTA), a combination of techniques from GIS-based spatial analysis and from corpus linguistics; second, enhanced close reading based on using place names or maps as query tools; and third, geographical analyses of the texts using techniques such as network analysis and route reconstruction. The aim of these three approaches is to go beyond simply producing visualisations, and instead to allow us to improve our understanding of the text with an emphasis on its geographies.
article_title: Digital approaches to understanding the geographies in literary and historical texts

abstract: This paper describes a number of techniques being developed by the Pelagios 3 project in order to facilitate production of Linked Open Data describing the toponymic content of early geospatial documents. It outlines two case studies, the first based on the text(s) of Vicarello Goblets, the second on a manuscript map of Claudius Ptolemy's Geographike Hyphegesis . These are used to demonstrate the extraction, and spatially located transcription of place names, along with identification in a URI-based gazetteer, and tools for their visualisation and comparison.
article_title: Pelagios 3: Towards the semi-automatic annotation of toponyms in early geospatial documents

abstract: This paper presents findings of an Andrew W. Mellon Foundation-funded project conducted at Penn State University in the period April 2012-June 2013. Through a web survey and ethnographic interviews, the project explored scholarly workflow of 196 Penn State faculty across the sciences, humanities, and social sciences, focusing on the integration of digital technologies at all stages of a research lifecycle—from collecting and analyzing data, over managing and storing research materials, to writing up and sharing research findings. This paper harvests a comparative multidisciplinary perspective of our study in order to explore specificities of humanities scholars’ digital workflow, providing a ground to identify and develop a software and service architecture that supports those practices. Therefore, while focusing on current findings, the paper briefly highlights the future trajectory of our study, as well as planned next steps regarding technological initiatives aimed at addressing management of digital scholarly workflow in humanities scholarship.
article_title: Tracing Workflow of a Digital Scholar

abstract: This presentation will discuss the current development and show demonstrations of the Scholarly 3D Toolkit, (S3DT) a plug-in for the Unity game engine designed to help better interface 3D historical reconstructions with other data. The work of a team lead by James Coltrain, S3DT will provide simple interfaces that allow creators to link their 3D scenes to sources and documents, and to dynamically import and view traditionally indexed digital humanities data from databases, spreadsheets, or GIS programs. The result will allow users to view multiple layers of data plotted within a single online 3D environment, showing markers for events, personal connections, documents, images, and annotations from multiple users, all in time and space.
article_title: The Scholarly 3D Toolkit: Annotation, Publication, and Analysis of 3D Scenes alongside Imported Humanities Data

affiliation: University of Nebraska, United States of America

abstract: The Tesserae project is n open-source, online tool for detecting allusions in Classical literature on an automated basis. This paper explores two methods for expanding Tesserae's capability to include allusions made across a language barrier, e.g. a Latin author alluding to a Greek text.
article_title: Automating the Search for Cross-language Text Reuse

affiliation: University at Buffalo, United States of America
University at Buffalo, United States of America
University at Buffalo, United States of America

abstract: My thesis aims to examine photographs from the British Raj (1850-1900) for the purposes of creating digital collections. The process of creating such a collection involves the attribution of metadata to each of the constituent images, and to the corpus as a whole. The photograph produces varied readings and thus poses a problem in the creation of their metadata. Whatever we can inscribe within the metadata is dependent on what we can articulate about that cultural object. My paper will explore the formation of metdata through the analysis (a combination of statistical and close-reading) of a body of annotated photographs. I propose to demonstrate means of extracting meaningful metadata in order to place them within established formats. I will also demonstrate new methods of visualising large image collection through the use of this form of analysis.
article_title: Readings of a photograph: Cognition and Access

abstract: The goal of this paper is to present some reflections about the process of building things in the Digital Humanities. It is based on our own experience in developing an analytic tool to study Internet Relay Chat (IRC) conversations within hacker and free and open source software communities.This paper will summarize the problematic as well as our objectives in the development of this tool. However, we propose to concentrate more of our presentation on a reflexive analysis of our own design activity in the development of this tool. We propose three axes of reflexive exploration about our experience in building the prototype : 1) reflexion about the studied material, 2) ethical aspects of designing the interface and 3) reflection on our design (and coding) practice.
article_title: Beyond the Tool : A Reflexive Analysis on Building Things in Digital Humanities

abstract: The Swiss Voice App, a smartphone application currently in development at the University of Zurich, is a follow-up project to the Dialäkt Äpp. The main purpose of both applications is to identify users’ dialects on the basis of the dialectal variants of 16 words. The Dialäkt Äpp users provide their pronunciation through buttons. However, the new Swiss Voice App asks users to pronounce the word and uses automatic speech recognition (ASR) to identify the variant. The Swiss Voice App further aims at illustrating the individuality in users’ voices by providing a multidimensional profile of their voice. The crowdsourced data obtained by both applications can be uses for research in dialectology, population statistics, etc.
article_title: Swiss Voice App: A smartphone application for crowdsourcing Swiss German dialect data

abstract: Perspective in novels is an important research topic in literary studies. This study analyzes the textual differences among perspectives in contemporary novels using computational stylistic methods, i.e., text classification and feature analyses by random forests. We selected two novels by Kotaro Isaka, a popular Japanese novelist, who explicitly switches perspective in his novels section by section. The results indicate that (a) perspectives have specific textual characteristics, (b1) textual characteristics specific to respective scenes such as proper nouns are important for differentiating perspective, and (b2) stylistic characteristics such as pronouns and nouns that represent styles of speech are also important. We conclude that computational stylistic methods are effective for analyzing the difference among perspectives in contemporary novels.
article_title: Analysis of perspectives in contemporary Japanese novels using computational stylistic methods

abstract: We present Biographical Elements and Structure Schema (BESS), a stand-aside XML schema used in the Collective Biographies of Women project. In addition to illustrating findings of the schema in analyzing networks of types of biographies--a team of editors tags types of narrative elements at the level of the paragraph--the talk addresses implications of team editing on a mid-range scale, between "distant" and "close" reading, data mining and textual editing. Visualizations of comparative analyses of short nonfiction narratives help to measure the changing conventions of representing individuals as well as types of women (8700 women) in the more than 13,300 biographies in more than 1200 books in our database. How might the human-curated method invite crowd sourcing? How would we adapt BESS for student research or classroom instruction, or for other prosopographies and other archives that include multiple versions of the same truthful narratives?
article_title: An XML Schema to Interpret Networked Biographies: Reading Mid-Range

affiliation: University of Virginia, United States of America
University of Virginia, United States of America

abstract: The appreciation of literature is a subjective process. This paper looks at book ratings on a book discussion site and tries to assess the role of individual readers' characteristics in these ratings. The question it tries to answer is whether the words that readers use can help explain which books they rate highly. I study a Dutch book discussion site. Looking at word usage patterns in several word categories (function words, cognitive, social and affective words), I show the existence of correlations between word frequencies and book ratings. I also show how usage of social words can help define a clustering of users that are clearly different in word usage and somewhat different in book preferences.
article_title: Dimensions of literary appreciation. Word use and ratings on a book discussion site

abstract: The “Architectural Practice in Post-War Queensland: Building and Interpreting an Oral History Archive” project is a collaboration between the University of Queensland, the State Library of Queensland (SLQ) and four of the longest-standing architectural firms in Queensland. The project’s aim is to build a comprehensive online multimedia digital archive that documents architectural practice in post-war Queensland (1945-1975) – a period that was highly significant but largely undocumented. This paper describes the innovative Semantic Web technologies that have been implemented to link tacit knowledge extracted from individual oral histories to tangible knowledge (drawings, books, photographs, manuscripts) that has been retrieved from personal, firm and State archives, digitized and uploaded to this online archive. It also describes the services that have been developed to enable architectural historians to document and discuss relationships between architects, firms, buildings/places and events.
article_title: Extracting Relationships from an Online Digital Archive about Post-War Queensland Architecture

abstract: The paper will address some of the most common and frequent needs and obstacles regarding legal issues in current digital scholarship (e.g. ownership of digital copies, electronic provision of source material) and demonstrate some of the consequent misconceptions, restrictions and legal traps which result from the lack of legal certainty due to the heterogeneous international legal situation regarding IPR and ancillary copyright. The Austrian example will be used to showcase some of the most obvious and momentous shortcomings of current IPR legislature, and will be compared with German and UK/US legal approaches. In conclusion, the paper will try to define a possible best practice which draws on the analysis of the common denominators found in (inter)national legal systems.
article_title: Intellectual Property Rights vs. Freedom of Research: Tripping stones in international IPR law

affiliation: Center for Information Modeling - Austrian Centre for Digital Humanities, University of Graz

abstract: Drawing on a novel dataset of nearly 5% of the top-level .ca domain preserved by the Internet Archive’s March 2011 Wide Web Scrape, this paper demonstrates how by using open-source software a researcher can move between the level of distant reading to the actual, preserved website. Mitigating the lack of a full-text search function in the WaybackMachine, this approach draws on clustering search engines to generate on-the-fly finding aids and search results.
article_title: Clustering Search to Navigate A Case Study of the Canadian World Wide Web as a Historical Resource

abstract: The SyMoGIH project (www.symogih.org) is an open modular platform for storing historical data and texts and includes the localization of historical information as a major issue. Consequently, a data model was built to treat the evolution of political and administrative territories taking their history into account, including their toponymic, typologic and spatial evolution. This paper outlines the implemented data model and describes the historical GIS (Geographic Information System) we are developing, called Geo-Larhra (www.geo-larhra.org), which includes a gazetteer and a digital historical atlas. We would like to promote an international collaboration on digital historical atlases.
article_title: SyMoGIH project and Geo-Larhra: A method and a collaborative platform for a digital historical atlas

abstract: The Día de las Humanidades Digitales/Dia das Humanidades Digitais initiative (DíaHD/DiaHD), based on the model of the international project Day in the Life of the Digital Humanities, aimed to answer the question of who is “we” in the context of the digital humanities community in Spanish and Portuguese-speaking countries. This social media experiment, which took place on June 10th 2013, offered indications of the different profiles of digital humanists in these communities, helping us to assess the challenges in developing the DH field in these countries and the additional effort needed to develop tools and to increase analytical studies of data in multilingual projects like this.
article_title: Who is we? The social media project: Día de las humanidades digitales/Dia das humanidades digitais

affiliation: niversidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico
Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico
Universidad Nacional de Educación Distancia, España
niversidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico
niversidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico
niversidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico

abstract: This paper describes several attempts to bridge a locally-developed DH-like community and the international DH community in Japan. ADHO already has been addressing it through MLMC committee and the SIG of the Global Outlook::Digital Humanities. The case should be useful for such activities so that DH can be more fruitful.
article_title: Bridging the Local and the Global in DH: A Case Study in Japan

affiliation: Graduate school of Humanities and Sociology, University of Tokyo
Graduate school of Humanities and Sociology, University of Tokyo

abstract: In this paper, we report the development of an innovative exhibition facility for digital humanities visualization. The development process involves a conceptual framework of place-making and an interaction design that exploits digital technological mediation of people and humanities. Similar to the museum experience with innovative engagement, the exhibition facility induces locative experience for sense-making and potentially plays a pivotal role in reaching wider audience for and facilitating further advance of digital humanities.
article_title: Developing a Physical Interactive Space for Innovative Digital Humanities Exhibition

affiliation: Natioanl Chengchi University, Taiwan, Republic of China
Natioanl Chengchi University, Taiwan, Republic of China

abstract: This paper describes the results of an interdisciplinary collaboration in which researchers, digital archivists and private companies created and to some extent negotiated web based dynamic visualizations to enrich publications. It presents the outcomes of an experiment with the development, preservation and reuse of animations of static illustrations of scientific laws, processes and the working of mechanical instruments and tools. The experiment did not limit itself to creation of animated visualizations, but comprehended workflows for re-use and the development of business models leading to animated discussions about historic methodologies, the ownership and responsibility of external links and issues of copy and author rights.
article_title: Dynamic Visualizations In Enriched Publications Of Seventeenth Century Science

affiliation: Huygens ING, The Hague/Museum Boerhaave Leiden, Netherlands

abstract: We contrast Ramsay's use of computer-assisted text analysis to spur literary insight, as advocated in Reading _Machines_ (2011), with Ellis & Favat's use of a computer in the 1960s to gain new insights into Huckleberry _Finn_ and to "enhance," they argue, what the literary critic already does. Ramsay's notion of deformance , linked to a conception of the speculative humanities that prizes the perpetuation of critical discussion, may de-emphasize attention to the algorithms being used to facilitate literary insight. To wit, we show in detail how the "deformed text" Ramsay produces from The _Waves_ using a tf-idf algorithm cannot be reproduced by the procedure he describes in Reading _Machines_. We show how carefully and accurately describing Ramsay's procedure (as he himself does not) engenders more valuable and more interesting conversations about literature and literary interpretation precisely because doing so foregrounds interpretative decisions and assumptions.
article_title: Starting the Conversation: Literary Studies, Algorithmic Opacity, and Computer-Assisted Literary Insight

affiliation: New York University, United States of America
New York University, United States of America

abstract: Software systems for presenting and analyzing texts have proliferated in recent decades as humanists have digitized more texts, and search is one of the core functionalities of these software systems. However, in displaying search results, digital tools have lacked one of characteristics of older print concordances, which typically present the key word in its context on one line of text with the context carefully chosen so as to maximize the reader’s understanding of the key word’s context given the space limitations. In this paper, I present an algorithmic approach to mimic a human’s activity in choosing the context for a given line length and font. This results in a presentation of search results almost as good as a human would choose without the tens or even hundreds of person-years required for traditional print concordances. Moreover, unlike print concordances, this algorithmic approach is flexible, accommodating changes in line length and font.
article_title: Marrying the Benefits of Print and Digital: Algorithmically Selecting Context for a Key Word

affiliation: University of Chicago, United States of America

abstract: Dans cette communication, nous approfondissons notre recherche sur la médiation culturelle et numérique en dehors du contexte muséal : à partir de chez soi, en préparation de la visite d’un monument, ou in situ en situation d’audioguidage. Nous souhaitons mieux cerner les enjeux d’une médiation numérique centrée sur les propriétés du patrimoine (cas de Pantheon Iview ) par opposition avec une médiation centrée sur l’expérience du visiteur ( Paris 3 D ) .Comment ces applications rendent-elles la complexité d’une architecture en reconfigurant l’expérience sensible de l’espace, du volume ? Notre problématique revient à interroger la puissance du numérique comme vision renouvelée du patrimoine et comme élargissement possible d’une expérience esthétique inédite. Cette communication questionne autant les modalités numériques de la médiation culturelle du patrimoine que la nature de l’information culturelle véhiculée par ces deux applications.
article_title: Quelle médiation numérique pour le patrimoine bâti ?

abstract: The proposal describes an approach to modelling the semantics of Medieval Legal Charters by two projects which work on material from the time of Charlemagne and Medieval Scotland. Extending the factoid model developed by DDH and successfully used by a number of prosopographical projects to cover characteristics of these legal charters allowed a model to be produced that makes explicit a possible understanding of the legal thinking of the people who created these charters. In this way, this work complements the text analysis and markup approaches to charter texts exemplified by other current work on digital representation of charters.
article_title: Exploring a model for the semantics of Medieval Legal Charters

affiliation: Department of Digital Humanities, King's College London, United Kingdom
Department of History, King's College London, United Kingdom
Department of History, University of Glasgos, United Kingdom
Department of History, University of Glasgos, United Kingdom

keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: Who says scholarship can’t be playful? Serendip-o-matic is a “serendipity engine” that was created in less than a week by twelve digital humanities scholars, developers, librarians. Designed to replicate the surprising experience of discovering an unexpected source while browsing library stacks or working in an archive, the visual and algorithmic design of Serendip-o-matic emphasizes playfulness. And since the tool was built by a group of people who weren’t yet sure of one another’s names, the process of building Serendip-o-matic was also rather playful. In this presentation, we report on how play shaped the creation, design, and marketing of Serendip-o-matic. We conclude by arguing for the benefits of more playful work in academic research and scholarship, as well as considering how such “play” can be evaluated in an academic context.
article_title: Play as Process and Product: On Making Serendip-o-matic

affiliation: Emory University, United States of America
State University of New York at New Paltz, United States of America

abstract: The Coptic language evolved from the language of the hieroglyphs of the pharaonic era and represents the last phase of the Egyptian language. It is pivotal for a wide range of humanistic disciplines, such as linguistics, biblical studies, the history of Christianity, Egyptology, and ancient history. Whereas languages like Classical Greek and Latin have enjoyed advances made in digital humanities with fully-fledged online research environments accessible to students and scholars (such as the Perseus Digital Library), until recently, no computational tools for Coptic have existed. Nor has an open digital research corpus been available. The research team developing Coptic SCRIPTORIUM (Sahidic Corpus Research: Internet Platform for Interdisciplinary multilayer Methods) is developing and providing open-source technologies and methodologies for interdisciplinary research across multiple disciplines in the Coptic language. This paper will address the automated tools we are developing for annotating and conducting research on a Coptic digital corpus.
article_title: Digitizing the Dead and Dismembered: DH Technologies for the Study of Coptic Texts

affiliation: University of the Pacific, United States of America

abstract: This paper will discuss the necessity for new methods of discovery in digitized newspapers and one approach advanced by the authors—the development of a software system for image processing to aid in the automated identification of poetic content in the 7 million newspaper pages available from Chronicling America. This paper will demonstrate the ability to identify poetic content in digitized newspapers and report on our findings applying and analyzing the image-based solution. The paper will conclude with a look at the lessons learned, the next steps, and broader implications of this research. Significantly, developing image processing as a methodology for humanities research and discovery means we can deal with multi-language corpora, since image analysis relies on visual patterns rather than textual patterns.
article_title: Detection of Poetic Content in Historic Newspapers through Image Analysis

affiliation: University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States of America
University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States of America
University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States of America
University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States of America

abstract: This paper reflects on the pros and cons of a mixed contributory, collaborative and co-creative model of community engagement (Bonney et al. 2009) with archaeology through crowd-sourcing and crowd-funding. It arises from a recently initiated project entitled Crowd and Community-fuelled Archaeological Research (a collaboration between the UCL Institute of Archaeology and The British Museum) that is developing a web platform (http://micropasts.org) to promote novel online communities that span hitherto different kinds of archaeological enthusiasts, from ‘traditional academics’, to already established groups of volunteer interest such as archaeological societies, and a wider crowd of as yet unknown contributors.
article_title: Mixing contributions, collaborations and co-creation: participatory archaeology through crowd-sourcing

affiliation: The Institute of Archaeology, University College London, United Kingdom
The Institute of Archaeology, University College London, United Kingdom

abstract: The Council on Library and Information Resources and the Library of Congress issued a 2010 report that suggests that if we do not use sound archives, our cultural heritage institutions will not preserve them. Nancy Davenport, previous president of CLIR, concludes that users want unfettered access and better discovery tools for what she calls “deep listening” (what Charles Bernstein calls “close listening”) or “listening for content, in note, performance, mood, texture, and technology.” It is a typical digital humanities problem: Without a better understanding of what such listening entails, we cannot build tools that afford such listening; because we lack the tools, humanists struggle to imagine how to describe the access they want -- what Jerome McGann calls “imagining what you don’t know.” In an attempt to imagine how to facilitate distant listening with computation, this paper positions user requirements for critical listening software within the context of critical listening theories.
article_title: Developing for Distant Listening: Developing Computational Tools for Sound Analysis By Framing User Requirements within Critical Theories for Sound Studies

affiliation: University of Texas at Austin, United States of America

keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: The Letters of 1916 Project is the first crowd-sourced digital humanities project in Ireland. Its goal is to create a crowd-sourced digital collection of letters written for a six-month period before and after the Easter Rising (1 November 1915 – 31 October 1916). The goal is to create a new online resource that will add a new and heretofore underutilised perspective to the events of the period that will form the basis for a revision of our understanding of life in Ireland in the early 20th Century. This paper will explore phase I of the project: the sourcing, gathering, and transcribing/encoding of collection. It will also document how the project is being used in the classroom at the Masters level.
article_title: Revisionism as Outreach: The Letters of 1916 Project

abstract: This paper addresses a critical issue that, as of yet, remains unanswered. Through direct engagement with notable digital writers, we explore issues of reusability and obsolescence in electronic literature. A historical account of the practice would suggest that closed formats seemingly dominate the electronic literary landscape, contrary to the open culture which writers, publishers and scholars working within this field tend to promote. In an effort to scrutinise this matter, we focus our attention on two of the field’s most prominent anthologies, the Electronic Literature Collection, Volume 1 (2006) and Volume 2 (2011), curated by the Electronic Literature Organization.
article_title: On Reusability and Electronic Literature

abstract: Quantitative analysis of literary texts is now well established in authorship attribution. However, there is also the potential for computational stylistics to make a contribution in stylometry beyond authorship attribution and in the wider area of literary interpretation. Here the problem of validation is acute. If a surprising finding emerges from a quantitative study, how can we tell a chance result, or an artefact of method, from a well-founded finding? The best first options may be other areas of classification, where validation is still possible, like chronology and genre study, but the bigger challenge and greatest rewards will be in interpretation in the wider sense. This panel approaches the question of validation in computational stylistics beyond authorship attribution through case studies in a variety of languages and literary traditions. Each case study discusses issues of validation and interpretation and offers some considerations of the wider questions of method which arise.
article_title: Validating Computational Stylistics in Literary Interpretation

affiliation: Pedagogical University of Kraków, Polish Academy of Sciences - Poland

abstract: I will present a mathematical approach to paleography for damaged manuscripts that incorporates both visual and contextual information in text identification. Improving and adapting a method initially conceived of by Derek Walvoord for text analysis of the Archimedes' Palimpsest, I intend to analyze spectral image data of the Vercelli Book, taken in March 2013 by Lazarus Project researchers and students, as well as myself. In this system, I intend to implement correlation filtering at the word, rather than the character level, and model the causal relationships between regions of interest at the sentence, rather than the word level, in order to improve and streamline text identification over existing methods. This project should serve to empower both paleographers and computer scientists alike, as it explores the relationship between traditional methods of text analysis and mathematical ones.
article_title: From the Archimedes’ Palimpsest to the Vercelli Book: Dual Correlation Pattern Recognition and Probabilistic Network Approaches to Paleography in Damaged Manuscripts

affiliation: University of Mississippi, United States of America

abstract: This paper discusses the design and outlines the challenges of a proposed “Digital Dutch East Asia Company (VOC) Linguistic Archive” project, which will grant unprecedented access to a wealth of historical linguistic data to a broad range of Western and non-Western researchers, from historians, to linguists and historical linguists, to researchers in Asian and colonial studies, allowing knowledge and skill exchange between groups previously working in isolation.
article_title: Digital Linguistic Archive of the Dutch East India Company (VOC): Modeling a community-sourcing platform for historical linguistic research

abstract: It has long been argued that Brian O’Nolan, operating under the pseudonym of Flann O’Brien, is a disciple of James Joyce. This paper examines the stylometric similarities between the two authors, particularly in relation to At Swim­Two­Birds and, to a lesser extent, The Hard Life, which we demonstrate are stylistically the most Joycean novels from O’Brien’s oeuvre. Emerging from a wider analysis of modernist writers (O’Sullivan, 2014), we will outline the results of a series of quantitative enquiries focused specifically on Joyce and O’Brien, before offering a number of literary interpretations.
article_title: Two Irish Birds: A Stylometric Analysis of James Joyce and Flann O’Brien

abstract: CLARIN is the short name for the Common Language Resources and Technology Infrastructure. It aims at providing easy and sustainable access for scholars in the humanities and social sciences to digital language data and advanced tools to discover, explore, exploit, annotate, analyse or combine them, independent of where they are located. CLARIN is in the process of building a networked federation of European data repositories, service centres and centres of expertise, with single sign-on access for all members of the academic community in all participating countries. The CLARIN infrastructure is still under construction, but a number of participating centres are already offering access services to data, tools and expertise. The purpose of the present paper is to give an overview of language resources, tools, and services that CLARIN presently offers.
article_title: CLARIN: Resources, Tools, and Services for Digital Humanities Research

abstract: The Research Programme in Digital Collections at the National Library of Wales researches the use and users of digital content, based on a number of evidence-based methods. From 2011-2013, the Library lad the development of a digital archive funded by the Joint Information Systems Committee (JISC), on the sources for the First World War in Wales Rhyfel Byd 1914-1918 a’r profiad Cymreig / Welsh experience of World War One 1914-1918. The development of this project was an opportunity to implement our theoretical understanding of what makes a digital resource have “value” and “impact” into the practical development of a digital resource in the humanities. This work will also provide a benchmark for measuring subsequent use and re-use of the resource. This presentation will discuss the process of developing the resource, and the factors that increase the value of digital collections for scholarship.
article_title: Building impact and value into the development of digital resources in the humanities: Rhyfel Byd 1914-1918 a’r profiad Cymreig / Welsh experience of World War One 1914-1918

affiliation: National Library of Wales, United Kingdom
National Library of Wales, United Kingdom
National Library of Wales, United Kingdom

abstract: After the East Japan Great Earthquake, women victims have been suffering from different problems and worries. However, it was difficult to grasp women victims’ requirements timely, because they were really patient and their needs were sometimes neglected under the environments and conditions that had changed from moment to moment. We need a more useful and easily way to obtain women victims’ needs. To properly detect and analyze needs of women victims, we set our research goal was a development of an advisory message board for women victims on the web. To achieve our goal, this paper aims to make clear issues for acquiring women victims’ needs and propose the frame work of an advisory message board for women victims after disasters. In our proposed message board, women victims can post their messages (requirements/opinions/complaints) freely, and data mining techniques are utilized to analyze messages and detect specific needs.
article_title: Framework of an Advisory Message Board for Women Victims after Disasters

abstract: Undertaking systematic analysis of large digitized corpora of broadcast news video archives and even smaller corpora of government information videos in the public record presents a number of technical, methodological, and institutional challenges. Although a deeper understanding of how the news is represented in moving images promises to improve access to historical records, participation in public dialogue, and education at all levels, large corpora of video news programs are considerably more difficult to catalog, mine, and visualize than text news collections. Furthermore, new forms of dissemination, annotation, and commentary made possible by the Internet are rapidly transforming video news consumption on a global scale. “Visualizing Global News” studies how excerpts from large collections of political speech videos with historically significant personages are remixed into even larger collections of news broadcasts.
article_title: Visualizing Global News

affiliation: University of California, San Diego, United States of America
CUNY Graduate Center, New York, United States of America

abstract: Leishu is a unique form of ancient Chinese reference books whose original purpose was to provide quick reference to ancient texts. A leishu usually contains two parts, a knowledge structure and a large number of texts quoted from earlier books. In this paper we present a study of two important leishu, yiwenleiju and taipingyulan, compiled in 624AD and 977AD, respectively. Through comparisons of the two knowledge structures and cited texts, we observed several significant changes in the worldview between the two era, which suggest that the rationalism movement of Song dynasty might already have begun in late Tang.
article_title: A glimpse of the change of worldview between 7th and 10th century China through two leishu

abstract: SALSAH (System for Annotation and Linkage of Sources in Arts and Humanities) version 2.0 is currently under development at the Digital Humanites Lab (DHLab) of the University of Basel. It is a browser-based VRE that provides simultaneous visualization of multiple digital objects (e.g., facsimile, images, texts, transcripts, sound, video), annotating digital objects and sharing these annotations with others, establishing relations (links) between digital objects which are subject to further annotations themselves, enabling access to and integration of external data sources (e.g., digital libraries) so that the VRE tools may be applied to external sources without the need of local duplicates, and transcription tools for manuscripts, speech and motion picture.
article_title: Future Development of a System for Annotation and Linkage of Sources in Arts and Humanities

abstract: The GeoBib project is constructing a georeferenced online bibliography of early Holocaust and Camp literature published between 1933 and 1949. Relations between persons, texts, and places will be visualized using digital maps and GIS software as an integral part of the resulting GeoBib information portal. The combination of diverse data from varying sources not only enriches our knowledge of these otherwise mostly forgotten texts; it also confronts us with vague, uncertain or even conflicting information. While the project operates at the intersection of historical and literary studies, the involved computer scientists are in charge of providing a working environment (Entrup et al. 2013b) and processing the collected information in a way that is formalized yet capable of dealing with inevitable vagueness, uncertainty and contradictions. In this paper we focus on the problems and opportunities of encoding and processing fuzzy data.
article_title: Uncertain about Uncertainty: Different ways of processing fuzziness in digital humanities data
keywords: data modeling and architecture including hypothesis-driven modeling

abstract: Alors que la réflexion sur la visualisation est au cœur de disciplines parfois émergentes, que la web véhicule un grand nombre de représentations souvent sophistiquées, introduisant de nouveaux modèles, souvent esthétiques mais qui nécessitent de nouveaux apprentissages pour la lecture et l’interprétation, de nombreuses disciplines s’appuient actuellement sur la visualisation pour communiquer leurs résultats ou créer des outils scientifiques. Cette contribution prend appui sur des champs disciplinaires différents pour proposer une réflexion sur la représentation des connaissances qui nous à conduit à développer un outil de visualisation des données textuelles.
article_title: Modèles tridimensionnels pour la représentation de l’état des connaissances et propositions de visualisation pour l’analyse des corpus textuels.

abstract: "Campus Medius" investigates mediality as historical experience, focusing on a chronotope of twenty-four hours in Vienna between May 13 and 14, 1933, and presented on two web-based platforms: an interactive map and an interactive documentary. Methodologically, the project relates Latour's actor-network theory to "dispositif" analysis following Foucault, directed at identifying the conditions under which the experiential field of modern media was able to emerge. The twenty-four hours under investigation are marked by so-called "Türkenbefreiungsfeiern." These events, celebrating the 250th anniversary of Vienna's liberation from the Turkish siege in 1683, were oriented from the outset upon processes of mass communication. "Campus Medius" reconstructs the media events of this time-space and traces them back to historical media "dispositifs." Hence, the project consists of two parts: a mapped topography of its actors within the Urban Research Tool and a narrated topology of the underlying knowledge forms, power relations, and subjectivation modes within Zeega.
article_title: CAMPUS MEDIUS--Topography and Topology of a Media Experience

abstract: The Riddle of Literary Quality runs at Huygens ING. The aim is to develop a method and the necessary software to analyze low level and high level formal features in a corpus of modern Dutch fiction, to find out whether formal features in the texts play a role in the reception and evaluation of the text by the readers. Can we distinguish texts found good or bad, literary or non-literary, by readers based on formal features in these texts? And how do the opinions of readers correlate with the kind of reader they are? The project aims to correlate formal features analyzed through a chain of μServices. Readers’ opinions and roles were assessed through an online survey and resulted in almost 14.000 respondents.
article_title: μServices and The Riddle of Literary Quality

abstract: Description (as opposed to narration) is an often underestimated element of prose fiction in literary theory. We aim to extract a specific type of description from recent Dutch novels, namely descriptions of characters' physical appearance. In this abstract, two methods for extraction are compared: (1) manual development of lexical-linguistic patterns and (2) a Naive Bayes and an SVM classifier. The tests are undertaken on a corpus of 16 chick-lit and 16 literary novels. Performance of the machine learning method (precision, recall and F-measure) is considerably better than that of the lexical-linguistic patterns. The patterns do however give better insight in the shape and format of the descriptions themselves. In future research, both methods might be combined to improve results.
article_title: Beautiful lips and porcelain cheeks: extracting physical descriptions from recent Dutch fiction

abstract: Describes the use of social network analysis to uncover new perspectives on medieval Scottish history with data from the People of Medieval Scotland database.
article_title: Using Social Network Analysis to Reveal Unseen Relationships in Medieval Scotland

abstract: Inicia-se por uma reflexão sobre as relações entre espaço material e espaço imaterial e como se podem potenciar os serviços de comunicação georeferenciados para dar novas camadas ao territórios, gerando um território hipersensível. Ou seja, os serviços de partilha de conteúdos suportados por dispositivos móveis georreferenciados criam a oportunidade de acrescentar novas camadas ao território tendo como suporte as nuvens. Com a possibilidade de associarmos os conteúdos ao território no qual foram gerados e/ou ao qual estão vinculados, porque os dispositivos tecnológicos passaram a incorporar sistema de GPS/bússola/GeoCMS, a materialidade do território voltou a ganhar um novo valor comunicacional, o valor de contexto. Com os novos mídia/serviços interconectados em rede passamos da geografia para a geomedia, para a relação geocultural e geoemocional mediada-aumentada. Apresentação dois projetos concretos desenvolvidos nessa lógica da informação e comunicação georeferenciada aplicada à fruição do território: Lookin e Bioduna.
article_title: A hipersensibilidade do Território – viver entre terra e nuvens

abstract: The breadth and scale of multimedia archives provides a tremendous potential for historical research that hasn't been fully tapped up to know. In this paper we want to discuss the approach taken by the History of Europe application, a demonstrator for the integration of human and machine computation that combines the power of face recognition technology with two distinctively dif- ferent crowdsourcing approaches to compute co-occurrences of persons in historical image sets. These co-occurrences are turned into a social graph that connects persons with each other and positions them, through information about the date and location of recording, in time and space. The resulting visualization of the graph as well as analytical tools can help historians to find new impulses for research and to unearth previously unknown relationships.
article_title: Building the social graph of the History of European Integration: A pipeline for the Integration of Human and Machine Computation

abstract: This paper focuses on the lack of tools to support a wide range of interactions with large-scale web archives. Although the capabilities offered by the Internet Archive and other commercial services are significant, we believe considerable technical advances are needed if web archives are to fulfill their promise as tools of analysis as well as preservation. We describe initiatives underway at the University of Maryland to partially redress the problem and highlight the need for qualitative user studies.
article_title: Supporting "Distant Reading" for Web Archives

affiliation: University of Maryland, United States of America
University of Maryland, United States of America
University of Maryland, United States of America

abstract: This paper reports on a comparative examination of two different approaches to presenting historical documents online. The first relied on a traditional textual introduction, the second provided the same information through a series of user-invoked Google pins. The crew agreement, a 19th century document detailing work on board a vessel of the British merchant marine, was used to see how undergraduate students navigate and learn to decipher a complex historical text. Extensive work with a small group of students revealed important lessons for anyone thinking of using a documentary series in a teaching environment or on a public history web site.
article_title: Realizing the democratic potential of online sources in the classroom

abstract: The Richmond Times Dispatch corpus of TEI-encoded newspapers comprises the Confederate newspaper’s Civil War run, 1860-1865. It is compelling both in terms of organization and content and amounts to a comprehensive textual index. In addition to the historical allure of its content, the formal properties of the digitized documents made available through the Perseus Collection make the Dispatch an extraordinary raw material for building a rich interactive visual experience that augments the textual one. This project demonstrates best practices for implementing a single-page application (SPA) using the emergent tools/frameworks found in modern web/social applications, which greatly facilitates the exploration of the Richmond Times Dispatch and can be generally applied to other TEI-based collections in future efforts (by us or others).
article_title: Single Page Apps for Humanists: A Case Study using the Perseus Richmond Times Corpus

affiliation: Loyola University Chicago, Center for Textual Studies and Digital Humanities
Loyola University Chicago, Center for Textual Studies and Digital Humanities

abstract: The goal of this research is to contribute to the development of information management tools by evaluating the relevance of knowledge extraction in information resources maintenance and development for performing arts such as dance. We obtain through knowledge extraction a vocabulary for describing and analyzing aesthetic experience of modern dance in archives. We worked from a corpus of texts including Stéphane Mallarmé’s collections Divagations and Poésies. Choreographic works were described using this vocabulary.
article_title: A vocabulary of the aesthetic experience for modern dance archives

abstract: “Digital Yoknapatawpha: Interpreting a Palimpsest of Place” reports on the collaborative effort of 25 scholars from around the world, led by Stephen Railton, to expand the understanding of Faulkner’s creation and recreation of this one county. This paper, written jointly by four of the project’s collaborators, will describe the digital methods and practices engaged in the project, as well as the inherent challenges produced when digital spaces encounter the fictional world of an author who did not care much about getting the facts right.
article_title: Digital Yoknapatawpha: Interpreting a Palimpsest of Place

affiliation: The New School for Liberal Arts, New York, New York

abstract: The proposed paper reports on the development of a new digital resource: EGO European History Online (EGO) is a transcultural history of modern Europe concentrating on processes of communication, interaction and interdependency. It is being published by the Leibniz Institute of European History (IEG) in Mainz in cooperation with the University of Trier’s Center for Digital Humanities. At its heart are transfer processes that extended across individual, familial and local realms and had a long-term impact. EGO traces these transfer processes in and between, amongst others, the realms of religion, law, politics, art, music, literature, economics, technology and the military, science and medicine. From the technical point of view EGO is based on a sophisticated infrastructure which supports the editorial board and is used to provide the online publication. For these purposes the content management system Plone is used, which is a very powerful environment developed for professional use.
article_title: Europe as a Digital Network: EGO European History Online

affiliation: Trier Center for Digital Humanities, Germany
Leibniz Institute of European History (IEG), Germany

abstract: We present Topotime, an open-source software project which includes a specification for encoding the kinds of temporal entities typically found in historical texts and some relationships between them; a graphical timeline layout program for parsing and rendering data written in that format; and related software tools to facilitate the encoding process, and transforming data into “temporal geometries” for further calculations of distance, similarity, and topological relations.
article_title: Topotime: Representing historical temporality

affiliation: Stanford University, United States of America
Stanford University, United States of America

abstract: In January 2014, the British Museum's departments of Learning, Volunteers and Audiences, in collaboration with the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) (http://finds.org.uk) and department of Britain, Europe and Prehistory; will be delivering an innovative video conferencing activity into several primary schools in the United Kingdom from the bowels of the British Museum's Samsung Digital Discovery Centre (SDDC). Building on the digital expertise delivered through the use of the PAS’s innovative and award winning website, curatorial and scientific staff and the world leading SDDC’s museum educational programmes, a new activity has been formulated. This activity will be aimed at teaching Key Stage 2 children a variety of life and ethical skills based around the amazing discovery of the Frome Hoard of 52,503 late Roman coins (Bland, Booth & Moorhead 2010) and the dispensation of the Treasure Act.
article_title: Treasure Challenge: an archaeological video conferencing journey

abstract: Collation is an important step in textual criticism and is often an arduous task for scholars involved in scholarly edition.Textual variation has been a pervasive problem affecting literary text. Finding variations is important for researchers in bibliography and book history as well. The area of collation awaits a lot more from technology. There is a need of a tool that can reduce the effort required in the collation process while maintaining (and sometimes improving) the usefulness and allowing scholars to use original documents (high quality facsimiles). This research focuses on this aspect of scholarly work and explores various approaches for performing digital collation in a seamlessly easy manner .A prototype of the virtual Hinman(vHinman) collator was created and user-evaluation was conducted amongst scholars experienced with collation work.. Image-matching algorithms along with context information are used to match words and the tool was integrated into the creativity support environment CritSpace
article_title: Aiding Modern Textual Scholarship using a Virtual Hinman Collator

affiliation: Texas A&M University, United States of America

abstract: In this presentation, we describe the development of two experimental prototypes, the "Glass Cast," a prototype for mapping and visualizing complex knowledge networks in which time is crucial, and on “PlotVis,” an interactive visualization resource for displaying XML-encoded fictional narratives that departs from ways of modeling narrative typical of literary pedagogy. In describing the considerations that informed the design and development of these in-progress prototypes, we contribute to ongoing theorization of the role of visualization, broadly conceived, in digital humanities scholarship. We also examine the implications for visualization of the metaphors implicit to the respective structures of our experimental prototypes. We ask, "How does metaphor shape and perhaps even constrain perceptions of the purpose of visualization, particularly as a way of thinking through complex problems?"
article_title: On Metaphor in Text Visualization Prototypes

abstract: Student participants in digital humanities -- defined broadly to include student workers, interns, and students enrolled in digital humanities classes -- can enable a digital humanities center to enhance and improve outreach and advocacy. Customary outreach activities are limited in their reach and effectiveness: bringing traditional humanities scholars into digital humanities scholarship is time and labor intensive, and publicity for projects and tools often targets specific audiences, leaving out constituencies that are institutionally or strategically important for the center’s growth. Student participants are often better situated than faculty to adopt digital technologies and approaches, and to serve as advocates for the center within and beyond the academy. We are developing our rationale and strategies to strengthen student involvement in digital scholarship with attention not only to potential benefits but also local constraints and ethical concerns.
article_title: Student Collaborators in Digital Humanities Outreach and Advocacy: Strategies and Examples from the IDHMC at Texas A&M University

abstract: Ce projet s’inscrit dans une réflexion sur la transmission du savoir, l’archivage et la constitution de la ou de mémoire(s) grâce aux outils numériques. Il s’agit d’éditer un corpus de sources variées - sources textuelles, mais aussi iconographiques, cartographiques - et de métaréflexions ayant trait à l'histoire de la Chine en tissant des liens entre les ressources documentaires grâce aux possibilités offertes par les technologies du web sémantique. Le déploiement des archives doit se faire sous la forme d'une représentation cartographique interactive.
article_title: L’édition numérique – système d’organisation des connaissances avec les outils sémantiques

abstract: This paper addresses the question: What role can library science and its methods play in the transmission of texts from codex to online? To address this question, this paper presents a library science derived model for facilitating codex to online textual transmission based on the work of textual theorist John Bryant’s fluid text theory. We briefly describe the model and how it provides a method for aggregating related bibliographical and archival evidence around a target text. We demonstrate the model by providing three examples. We seek to illustrate the potential of the fluid text theory in providing a model for textual transmission online that unlocks the latent information surrounding those texts contained in libraries and archives. We then close speculating on what type of documenting infrastructure would be needed for citing such textual influences in an online publishing environment absent the familiar pages and page numbering of the codex.
article_title: Reconstruction and Display of a Nineteenth Century Landscape Model

abstract: Synthesizing current research on exploratory data analysis with techniques from the fields of computational linguistics and data visualization, we propose a new set of methods-- a component of our NEH-funded TOME project (Interactive TOpic Model and MEtadata Visualization)-- to assist humanities scholars in computationally-assisted exploratory research. More specifically, we ask how the exploratory thematic analysis of documents might be incorporated into the initial phase of humanities research, while remaining accessible to non-technical scholars. Our examples derive from the antislavery newspapers of the 19th-century United States, which are significant not only because they function as the primary record of the sociopolitical machinations that culminated in slavery’s abolition, but also because they are among the earliest examples of women writing alongside men for a general audience. Our analysis thus reveals how passed between social and political coalitions, with an emphasis on how ideas were framed differently by male and female writers.
article_title: Exploratory Thematic Analysis for Historical Newspaper Archives

abstract: This paper describes the Early Modern European Social History Geo-Spatial Bibliography project (EMESHGB), a project that uses a geo-spatial and temporal interface to give access to a bibliographic database of historical works about early modern Europe written since the 1950s. The work is "deeply annotated" in that the basic MARC records included in the database is supplemented with information about social science topics, methods, and sources used, so that comparisons between localities can be made.
article_title: A "Deeply Annotated" Bibliography of Local Social Histories of Early Modern Europe

affiliation: Richard Stockton College of New Jersey, United States of America

abstract: Big data analytics and computer-supported visualization offer ways to read collections as our cognitive abilities are stretched to their limit with the sheer volume of data available. It is important to question if the visual models emerging can better be designed to suit humanities exploration. In this paper we propose to examine visualization for text mining by surveying commonly used graphical representations, identifying the visualizations that humanists find most useful, scaling these so they can be used interactively to explore large data sets, and producing prototypes to verify our findings. The goal is visualizations that help researchers make sense of big data; visualizations that let us explore the forest, not just the trees so that we can draw accurate and appropriate inferences from the data.
article_title: Seeing the Trees & Understanding the Forest

abstract: In this article, we examine the application of computational stylometry to psychological profiling. We adapt several techniques which have proven useful for author identification to the problem of predicting various aspects of a user’s personality. In previous work, we were able to identify the user’s Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) by analyzing an essay written by that user. Here, we adapt the MBTI prediction system to work by analyzing a user’s computer usage instead. We also introduce systems to predict the user’s most preferential Multiple Intelligences Developmental Assessment Scales (MIDAS) subcategories.
article_title: Active Authentication through Psychometrics

affiliation: Juola & Associates, United States of America

abstract: The development and combination of four cores, CorPix, CorTex, CorCode and CorForm, within the modular and adaptable framework Mojulem, has allowed the second phase of the Woolf Online project to begin to approach the following fundamental questions about the nature and development of literature: how does a literary text come into being? what kinds of influence are at work upon the writer during the process of initial composition, and thereafter? As such, this paper and presentation will outline and demonstrate visual methods and considerations for implementing such perceived networked histories. It will also discuss the different aspects of the framework Mojulem, and its four fundamental cores, and ground such a discussion within the example of the ongoing Woolf Online project.
article_title: From lighthouse to framework: visualising digital scholarly editions with pathways and histories

affiliation: Loyola University Chicago, United States of America

abstract: Archaeology and epigraphy have made significant progress to decipher the hieroglyphic writings of the Ancient Maya, but the long-standing goal remains unfinished, as a significant proportion of the Maya hieroglyphic corpus is still open for interpretation.In this short paper, we present an overview of the MAAYA project, an interdisciplinary effort that integrates the work of Maya epigraphists and computer scientists to adress three goals: (1) Design, development, and evaluation of computational tools for visual analysis and digital information management that effectively support the work of Maya hieroglyphic scholars; (2) Advancement of the state of Maya epigraphy through the coupling of expert knowledge and the use of these tools; and (3) Design and implementation of mechanisms to share these resources with the scholar community through the creation of an online system that supports search and retrieval, comparison, annotation, and visualization tasks.
article_title: The MAAYA Project: Multimedia Analysis and Access for Documentation and Decipherment of Maya Epigraphy

abstract: Nowadays, large collections of historical manuscripts exist, which contain valuable information about our cultural heritage. Recently, there has been much interest in their digitization for preservation reasons. Digitization though is only the first step to make the information contained in manuscripts accessible to researchers and to the interested public. Further processing steps need to be applied, so that the manuscript's content is transformed into a form that is interpretable by a computer. One important step is that of text line extraction. In this paper, we propose a binarization-free text line extraction method using seam carving. The main idea is to compute an energy map of the input text blocks and determine minimum energy paths through them. The energy map is constructed in a way so that gaps between text lines have low energy values and a minimum energy path will successfully pass through these gaps.
article_title: Binarization-free Text Line Extraction for Historical Manuscripts

abstract: Una red científica está formada por el conjunto de actores de la red (investigadores, centros, revistas, temas de investigación, etc.) y por el conjunto de asociaciones establecidas entre ellos. Los actores independientemente de su naturaleza pueden definirse mediante palabras. Se ha realizado el análisis dinámico de la red científica relacionada con el descriptor “historia del arte” en el periodo 1976-2012. Se han empleado técnicas KDD (knowledge databases discovery), de text mining (coword analysis), para obtener las subredes de investigación más importantes y relevantes de cada subperiodo. Se ha obtenido el diagrama dinámico o de series temáticas que permite el análisis y la visualización de la evolución de los resultados de la investigación.
article_title: Aplicación del análisis dinámico de redes científicas al estudio de la evolución de la investigación española relacionada con el descriptor “historia del arte” durante 1976-2012, según ISOC.

abstract: The National Institute for Japanese Language and Linguistics (NINJAL) is conducting morphological analysis on Japanese classics. Digitization has been done thus far on the literature of several ages and various text corpora have been published. However, each element of the text corpora is marked up under NINJAL’s Document Type Definition, which is basically neither unified nor standardized. Under this circumstance it causes problems with structural analysis and numerical analyses between several corpora. Thus, it is necessary to mark up texts using a unified definition from a higher level to conduct analyses concurrently. In the previous study, we examined the possibility of converting classic documents with TEI-compliant XML by designing a tag-set and strictly structuring a wood-block printed book from Sharebon’s as a model case. In this study, we further examine the problems of (A) text formatting on character data level and (B) structuring ruby annotation which were previously unsolved.
article_title: Problems in Encoding Documents of Early Modern Japanese
